commit_message:
Fix bash_completion cache path

In change 4cf62cf3 we started writing the
cache to ~/.cache/cinderclient/ - this script
needs to read from there.

Related-Bug: #1712835

Change-Id: Ib4de058af6b636d06ac360fe448b432e8e7733ad

subject: Install python-panko client
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 6924, 'name': 'Pradeep Kilambi', 'email': 'pkilambi@redhat.com', 'username': 'pkilambi'}, {'_account_id': 7144, 'name': 'James Slagle', 'email': 'jslagle@redhat.com', 'username': 'slagle'}, {'_account_id': 10873, 'name': 'Juan Antonio Osorio Robles', 'email': 'jaosorior@redhat.com', 'username': 'ejuaoso'}, {'_account_id': 14985, 'name': 'Alex Schultz', 'email': 'aschultz@next-development.com', 'username': 'mwhahaha'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 23181, 'name': 'RDO Third Party CI', 'email': 'dmsimard+rdothirdparty@redhat.com', 'username': 'rdothirdparty', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 28504, 'name': 'Vinay Kapalavai', 'email': 'vkapalav@redhat.com', 'username': 'vkapalav'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 28504, 'date': '2018-11-26 21:40:51.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 14985, 'date': '2018-11-27 17:11:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 7144, 'date': '2019-01-11 20:08:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

i don't see how this fixes the issue described in the bug. Could you elaborate?

You'd still need to set enable_telemetry=true for this fix to take effect. From the bug description, it sounds like you deployed panko in the *overcloud*, and then tried to use client libraries on the undercloud that were not installed.

I don't have a major problem with this patch, it's just that enable_telemetry as an undercloud configuration is independent of what you deployed in the overcloud."}, {'account_id': 14985, 'date': '2019-01-11 20:23:46.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

if you enable it on the overcloud but not on the undercloud, you can't run panko related commands from the undercloud. In future versions this was addressed by installing all the clients on the undercloud seperately"}, {'account_id': 7144, 'date': '2019-01-14 21:38:42.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> if you enable it on the overcloud but not on the undercloud, you
 > can't run panko related commands from the undercloud. In future
 > versions this was addressed by installing all the clients on the
 > undercloud seperately

Yes. I know you need the clients installed on the undercloud if you intend to use the undercloud as the client machine to talk to overcloud services.

This patch is much more than just installing the client though. As I said in my review, you have to set enable_telemetry=true for the undercloud in order to get the client installed. Which means, in order to get the client installed, you must enable all telemetry services on the undercloud.

That is not the right fix for the linked bug."}, {'account_id': 14985, 'date': '2019-01-14 21:51:14.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

oh actually the existing functionality what we don't have today. I think the issue is that we used to always include panko::client in puppet-panko and we switched that during the pike release so we didn't."}, {'account_id': 7144, 'date': '2019-01-25 18:15:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

if the point here is to make sure the client is installed so that communication with overcloud services is possible, then I think it's the wrong approach to say "you must also enable the telemetry services on the undercloud to get the client installed".

why don't we just always install the client regardless of the value of enable_telemetry?'}, {'account_id': 28504, 'date': '2019-01-25 19:12:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> if the point here is to make sure the client is installed so that
 > communication with overcloud services is possible, then I think
 > it's the wrong approach to say "you must also enable the telemetry
 > services on the undercloud to get the client installed".
 > 
 > why don't we just always install the client regardless of the value
 > of enable_telemetry?

Since we can install telemetry on overcloud regardless in undercloud, I feel it make sense to add panko client regardless of enable_telemetry parameter.'}, {'account_id': 28504, 'date': '2019-01-25 19:13:45.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 28504, 'date': '2019-01-25 19:14:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> > if the point here is to make sure the client is installed so that
 > > communication with overcloud services is possible, then I think
 > > it's the wrong approach to say "you must also enable the
 > telemetry
 > > services on the undercloud to get the client installed".
 > >
 > > why don't we just always install the client regardless of the
 > value
 > > of enable_telemetry?
 > 
 > Since we can install telemetry on overcloud regardless in
 > undercloud, I feel it make sense to add panko client regardless of
 > enable_telemetry parameter.

Then in that case it should be the same for pike branch as well.?'}, {'account_id': 7144, 'date': '2019-01-29 22:53:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2

recheck'}, {'account_id': 6924, 'date': '2019-01-30 17:04:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2

recheck'}, {'account_id': 10873, 'date': '2019-02-19 13:14:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 7144, 'date': '2019-02-20 02:00:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

2019-02-19 13:43:18 | 2019-02-19 13:43:18,615 INFO: \x1b[1;31mError: Evaluation Error: Error while evaluating a Function Call, Could not find class ::panko::client for centos-7-ovh-gra1-0002710279 at /etc/puppet/manifests/puppet-stack-config.pp:327:1 on node centos-7-ovh-gra1-0002710279\x1b[0m
http://logs.openstack.org/66/620166/2/check/tripleo-ci-centos-7-undercloud-oooq/3f98401/logs/undercloud/home/zuul/undercloud_install.log.txt.gz#_2019-02-19_13_43_18'}, {'account_id': 28504, 'date': '2019-02-21 18:09:44.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 6924, 'date': '2019-02-21 22:00:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

pankoclient doesnt exist in ocata FYI'}, {'account_id': 6924, 'date': '2019-02-21 22:02:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

from what i understand in the bug, the issue is with pike not ocata code. After upgrade we want to ensure pankoclient is installed if telemetry is enabled. So this patch should be to pike branch?'}, {'account_id': 28504, 'date': '2019-02-21 22:12:52.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

Pushed change to incorrect branch.'}]

[{'created': '2019-02-20 19:30:27.000000000', 'message': 'Heat: Add enable_proxy_headers_parsing to config file

Adding this parameter will allow forwarding messages with htpps.

Change-Id: Ib99a16b6252b15d9f138417485731ec401cb8f81
'}, {'created': '2019-02-20 19:50:22.000000000', 'message': 'Heat: Add enable_proxy_headers_parsing to config file

commit_message:
enable_proxy_headers_parsing to various services.

Adding this parameter to Cinder, Heat, Glance,and Neutron
config. Adding this parameter allows proper handling to resource
links in response using API services behind https proxy.

Change-Id: Ib99a16b6252b15d9f138417485731ec401cb8f81

commit_message:
Enable has_install_guide for the Placement project

The index page of the install guide has been added
in the Placement project
since I2f7bcd8efabc628bd27e3a9ce74e277a9e37fb69.
So enable the has_install_guide flag for the Placement project.

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/628220/
Change-Id: I1f92c84c3faae6420adff2b267feaef54ddcc454

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-02-08 09:09:32.000000000', 'message': "Ensure notifications are consumed from non-pool queue

When using oslo.messaging notifications and all listeners
are using a pool. The messages published to the default
notification queue is never consumed, only the pool queues
are consumed. The queue that is not consumed keep growing
and is using more and more RAM on the system where the
message broker is running.

Also prefix the pool names so that it's easier for someone
looking at queues in the messaging backend to identify the
source.

Related-Bug: #1814544
Story: 2004938
Task: 29404
Change-Id: I7b3e0db64b7b7d3372e5ca24cea88b4b897651be
(cherry picked from commit 9da983270343bea89c18804767b1532c39c59622)
"}]
commit_message:
Ensure notifications are consumed from non-pool queue

When using oslo.messaging notifications and all listeners
are using a pool. The messages published to the default
notification queue is never consumed, only the pool queues
are consumed. The queue that is not consumed keep growing
and is using more and more RAM on the system where the
message broker is running.

Also prefix the pool names so that it's easier for someone
looking at queues in the messaging backend to identify the
source.

Related-Bug: #1814544
Story: 2004938
Task: 29404
Change-Id: I7b3e0db64b7b7d3372e5ca24cea88b4b897651be
(cherry picked from commit 9da983270343bea89c18804767b1532c39c59622)

[{'account_id': 10267, 'date': '2019-01-21 14:24:31.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 10267, 'date': '2019-01-21 14:27:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

[1] http://paste.openstack.org/show/743045/'}, {'account_id': 26622, 'date': '2019-01-21 16:00:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Build succeeded.

- neutron http://cloudbase-ci.com/neutron/632098/1 : SUCCESS in 1h 35m 29s'}, {'account_id': 11816, 'date': '2019-01-21 17:07:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

AFAICT this is wrong, as is the one in https://review.openstack.org/#/c/534449/.    Neutron spins up multiple processes right on startup and in an HA environment will also have multiple Neutron services on many hosts.   This synchronization decorator is only applying a thread level lock.   if the performance problem being repaired is that there were too many conflicts causing a rollback, this won't achieve anything in the vast majority of high scale environments except for more locking of unrelated records against each other.  Also, is neutron using a threaded implementation  under mod_wsgi these days?  or still running eventlet server ?"}, {'account_id': 24245, 'date': '2019-01-21 20:00:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

> AFAICT this is wrong, as is the one in https://review.openstack.org/#/c/534449/.
 >    Neutron spins up multiple processes right on startup and in an
 > HA environment will also have multiple Neutron services on many
 > hosts.   This synchronization decorator is only applying a thread
 > level lock.   if the performance problem being repaired is that
 > there were too many conflicts causing a rollback, this won't
 > achieve anything in the vast majority of high scale environments
 > except for more locking of unrelated records against each other. 
 > Also, is neutron using a threaded implementation  under mod_wsgi
 > these days?  or still running eventlet server ?

Right, the synchronize operator only helps on a single node. But without it you end up getting conflicts on a single node causing a retry wich will start with a delay of 0.5 seconds before retry. On subsequent retries the delay will increase[1].

By serializing and a single neutron host is used the speedup is great as (as far as I understand) there are 0 conflicts. With multiple hosts there will be conflicts, and retry delays. However, hopefully, the first host that kick of the creates will be able to complete several creates before the is another conflict instead of immideatly conflicting with itself.


I'm by no means an SQL expert, but I remember thinking that there must be an underlying bad behavior in how neutron db object are implemented.

I think this change would increase performance for a lot of users, so I'll +1.
But! I think Michael is correct, as I understand it, the more neutron nodes the slower things will go.
It would be good to open a bug to return to this and find a solution that truly scales.



[1] https://github.com/openstack/neutron-lib/blob/master/neutron_lib/db/api.py#L150-L154"}, {'account_id': 11816, 'date': '2019-01-21 20:52:25.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: -Code-Review

 > > level lock.   if the performance problem being repaired is that
 > > there were too many conflicts causing a rollback, this won't
 > > achieve anything in the vast majority of high scale environments
 > > except for more locking of unrelated records against each other.
 > > Also, is neutron using a threaded implementation  under mod_wsgi
 > > these days?  or still running eventlet server ?
 > 
 > Right, the synchronize operator only helps on a single node. But
 > without it you end up getting conflicts on a single node causing a
 > retry wich will start with a delay of 0.5 seconds before retry. On
 > subsequent retries the delay will increase[1].
 > 
 > By serializing and a single neutron host is used the speedup is
 > great as (as far as I understand) there are 0 conflicts. With
 > multiple hosts there will be conflicts, and retry delays. However,
 > hopefully, the first host that kick of the creates will be able to
 > complete several creates before the is another conflict instead of
 > immideatly conflicting with itself.
 > 
 > 
 > I'm by no means an SQL expert, but I remember thinking that there
 > must be an underlying bad behavior in how neutron db object are
 > implemented.


I was saying similar on a different thread, that this reduces the number of retries per process but the issue requiring the retries in the first place is troublesome.


 > 
 > I think this change would increase performance for a lot of users,
 > so I'll +1.
 > But! I think Michael is correct, as I understand it, the more
 > neutron nodes the slower things will go.
 > It would be good to open a bug to return to this and find a
 > solution that truly scales.


I agree with all of that.



 >

 > 
 > [1] https://github.com/openstack/neutron-lib/blob/master/neutron_lib/db/api.py#L150-L154"}, {'account_id': 10980, 'date': '2019-01-21 23:15:19.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

You're fixing an issue by accident here. The actual fix should be a lock for the process on the security group id.  I have Liu testing that for the other patch, and if it works for him, I think we should fold that in with the other fix. Find me on irc (@dougwig), let's merge them."}, {'account_id': 10980, 'date': '2019-01-21 23:22:35.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Try this instead, on top of 628691:

diff --git a/neutron/db/securitygroups_db.py b/neutron/db/securitygroups_db.py
index dfe3c7df38..5866b5a96f 100644
--- a/neutron/db/securitygroups_db.py
+++ b/neutron/db/securitygroups_db.py
@@ -25,6 +25,7 @@ from neutron_lib.db import utils as db_utils
 from neutron_lib import exceptions as n_exc
 from neutron_lib.utils import helpers
 from neutron_lib.utils import net
+from oslo_concurrency import lockutils
 from oslo_utils import uuidutils
 import six
 from sqlalchemy.orm import scoped_session
@@ -333,7 +334,8 @@ class SecurityGroupDbMixin(ext_sg.SecurityGroupPluginBase):
             ret = []
             for rule_dict in rules:
                 res_rule_dict = self._create_security_group_rule(
-                    context, rule_dict, validate=False)
+                    context, rule_dict, validate=False,
+                    sg_id=security_group_id)
                 ret.append(res_rule_dict)
         for rdict in ret:
             registry.notify(
@@ -350,7 +352,7 @@ class SecurityGroupDbMixin(ext_sg.SecurityGroupPluginBase):
         return res
 
     def _create_security_group_rule(self, context, security_group_rule,
-                                    validate=True):
+                                    validate=True, sg_id=None):
         if validate:
             sg_id = self._validate_security_group_rule(context,
                                                        security_group_rule)
@@ -391,22 +393,23 @@ class SecurityGroupDbMixin(ext_sg.SecurityGroupPluginBase):
         self._registry_notify(resources.SECURITY_GROUP_RULE,
                               events.BEFORE_CREATE,
                               exc_cls=ext_sg.SecurityGroupConflict, **kwargs)
-        with db_api.CONTEXT_WRITER.using(context):
-            if validate:
-                self._check_for_duplicate_rules(context, sg_id,
-                                                [security_group_rule])
-            sg_rule = sg_obj.SecurityGroupRule(context, **args)
-            sg_rule.create()
-
-            # fetch sg_rule from db to load the sg rules with sg model
-            # otherwise a DetachedInstanceError can occur for model extensions
-            sg_rule = sg_obj.SecurityGroupRule.get_object(context,
-                                                          id=sg_rule.id)
-            res_rule_dict = self._make_security_group_rule_dict(sg_rule.db_obj)
-            kwargs['security_group_rule'] = res_rule_dict
-            self._registry_notify(resources.SECURITY_GROUP_RULE,
-                              events.PRECOMMIT_CREATE,
-                              exc_cls=ext_sg.SecurityGroupConflict, **kwargs)
+        with lockutils.lock(sg_id):
+            with db_api.CONTEXT_WRITER.using(context):
+                if validate:
+                    self._check_for_duplicate_rules(context, sg_id,
+                                                    [security_group_rule])
+                sg_rule = sg_obj.SecurityGroupRule(context, **args)
+                sg_rule.create()
+
+                # fetch sg_rule from db to load the sg rules with sg model
+                # otherwise a DetachedInstanceError can occur for model extensions
+                sg_rule = sg_obj.SecurityGroupRule.get_object(context,
+                                                              id=sg_rule.id)
+                res_rule_dict = self._make_security_group_rule_dict(sg_rule.db_obj)
+                kwargs['security_group_rule'] = res_rule_dict
+                self._registry_notify(resources.SECURITY_GROUP_RULE,
+                                      events.PRECOMMIT_CREATE,
+                                      exc_cls=ext_sg.SecurityGroupConflict, **kwargs)
         return res_rule_dict
 
     def _get_ip_proto_number(self, protocol):"}, {'account_id': 10980, 'date': '2019-01-21 23:23:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

But, ultimately, I think we should punt this up to a db wide fix, rather than per object.'}, {'account_id': 10267, 'date': '2019-01-22 03:24:04.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Thanks Doug, yesterday I tried this (taking lock on security group) http://paste.openstack.org/show/743072/ but couldn't push as it was late night (India time) and was trying to understand for which records we are trying to hold write lock http://paste.openstack.org/show/743073/ 

I will rebase this on top of https://review.openstack.org/#/c/628691/"}, {'account_id': 10267, 'date': '2019-01-22 15:19:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Can you please also check https://review.openstack.org/#/c/632479/ ?

We can avoid locks with this change.'}, {'account_id': 9531, 'date': '2019-01-22 15:47:17.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

(2 comments)

> Can you please also check https://review.openstack.org/#/c/632479/
 > ?
 > 
 > We can avoid locks with this change.
Seems OVN guys need to confirm that change.



-1 for waiting the test results, I'd like to see the 'duplicated-request' scenario test results."}, {'account_id': 10980, 'date': '2019-01-22 15:58:14.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

The other thing to consider with this change, is that it's optimizing an UNLIKELY case, at the cost of the LIKELY case.  If you test with differing security groups (or even just pairs), this lock will stop helping and start hurting. We really need to address the underlying issues with how contention is handled."}, {'account_id': 10980, 'date': '2019-01-22 16:03:43.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Also, fwiw, when I test the lock fix (both yours and mine), I see significant variability and worse performance in the _normal_ cases, where sg_id's aren't all exactly the same. I haven't traced down why, but I'm guessing it's the overhead and/or implementation of the locks themselves."}, {'account_id': 10980, 'date': '2019-01-22 16:06:29.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I haven't test it, but I'd wager you'd get this on *any* neutron API in which we flood that same object id, since it's retry contention at issue. And we should add locks to everything..."}, {'account_id': 11816, 'date': '2019-01-22 16:33:54.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> The other thing to consider with this change, is that it's
 > optimizing an UNLIKELY case, at the cost of the LIKELY case.  If
 > you test with differing security groups (or even just pairs), this
 > lock will stop helping and start hurting. We really need to address
 > the underlying issues with how contention is handled.


+1000 adding locks makes me very nervous"}, {'account_id': 11816, 'date': '2019-02-21 19:10:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

should this be abandoned now that I2fef298041c59a03dfd06912764973995b80690c has merged?'}, {'account_id': 1131, 'date': '2019-02-21 20:54:01.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

commit_message:
Improve security group rule create performance

[1] says serializing the method with lockutils improves the API
performance. When tried that on security group rule create, by creating
300 security group rules asynchronously, max time taken for the API to
finish was 51 seconds[2] comapred to 390 seconds[3] taken for the API
without this change. Also all the 300 calls were succesful with this
patch, whereas some were failing with the existing code.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/534449/
[2] http://paste.openstack.org/show/743043/
[3] http://paste.openstack.org/show/743042/

Change-Id: I2045d7ff0a36a28311c09c667b2841487dd81d71

As I said on the other patch, let's be very cautious in "fixing" really unlikely test cases (namely, 300 calls to the _same_ security group), without also rigorously testing the more common cases. Not voting on this patch, as I don't know the implications of adding this toggle.'}, {'account_id': 23804, 'date': '2019-01-22 16:05:35.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I see value on this patch, I don't think we need to increment SG rev number every time we deal with SG rules. We may need to accommodate networking-ovn for this but, as I said, it makes sense to me. That said, I can't really tell which other implications there might be for other projects."}, {'account_id': 6773, 'date': '2019-01-22 16:07:44.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> I see value on this patch, I don't think we need to increment SG
 > rev number every time we deal with SG rules. We may need to
 > accommodate networking-ovn for this but, as I said, it makes sense
 > to me. That said, I can't really tell which other implications
 > there might be for other projects.

++

I was taking a look at the networking-ovn code and it should be grand on our side. We have a distinction between the SG revision numbers [0] and the SG Rule revision number [1].

[0]https://github.com/openstack/networking-ovn/blob/b77daa2f12c558e8ea8b3f0599a1fab4ffca0ab1/networking_ovn/common/ovn_client.py#L1687

[1] https://github.com/openstack/networking-ovn/blob/b77daa2f12c558e8ea8b3f0599a1fab4ffca0ab1/networking_ovn/common/ovn_client.py#L1736"}, {'account_id': 23804, 'date': '2019-01-22 16:16:14.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Cool thanks Lucas for taking a look.
I thought we would need to change anything in our side cause ideally we dont want to bump SG rev number just because an SGR was added. So if this is currently being done and we're not doing anything, we expect the maint task in networking-ovn to fix it every time which is useless."}, {'account_id': 6773, 'date': '2019-01-22 16:17:56.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> Cool thanks Lucas for taking a look.
 > I thought we would need to change anything in our side cause
 > ideally we dont want to bump SG rev number just because an SGR was
 > added. So if this is currently being done and we're not doing
 > anything, we expect the maint task in networking-ovn to fix it
 > every time which is useless.

Exactly, this could actually help us by not creating an inconsistency when a SG rule is added to a SG."}, {'account_id': 9531, 'date': '2019-01-22 16:18:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

> I see value on this patch, I don't think we need to increment SG

+1, this can be one improvement. But I have one concern, what happened to the remove_security_group if no reversion of the sg? But at the same time, we do not increase the reversion num for network/subnet for every port creation, right?"}, {'account_id': 26622, 'date': '2019-01-22 16:19:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Build succeeded.

- neutron http://cloudbase-ci.com/neutron/632479/1 : SUCCESS in 1h 35m 57s'}, {'account_id': 10267, 'date': '2019-01-22 17:43:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> > I see value on this patch, I don't think we need to increment SG
 > > rev number every time we deal with SG rules. We may need to
 > > accommodate networking-ovn for this but, as I said, it makes
 > sense
 > > to me. That said, I can't really tell which other implications
 > > there might be for other projects.
 > 
 > +1, this can be one improvement. But I have one concern, what
 > happened to the remove_security_group if no reversion of the sg?
sg has revision numbers in standardattribute table, for create/update/delete operations on security group, this revision number is updated. 
"remove_security_group" has removed the corresponding record from standardattribute table (tested in my setup). 

 > But at the same time, we do not increase the reversion num for
 > network/subnet for every port creation, right?
Thanks, you got my point :) I feel the same. When we create/update/delete port, we don't update revision number for network. Similarly I feel no need to update revision number for security group, when we create/update/delete security group rule.'}, {'account_id': 10267, 'date': '2019-01-23 02:36:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

One of them "test_security_group_rule_ops_bump_security_group" is expecting that SG revision version to be bumped.

Also, I agree with Miguel about contacting other projects/PTLs (or tagging them in this review)'}, {'account_id': 1131, 'date': '2019-02-04 03:19:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Oops, mis-click. Are we sure about breaking backwards compat here? The "correct" fix would be for the client to use bulk create. Though honestly, the really "correct" change would be to actually CRUD on sg's and sg rule's separately, so we weren't dragging around lists of child objects on every operation. But that ship has sailed in api v2.'}, {'account_id': 26622, 'date': '2019-02-04 17:40:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Build succeeded.

- neutron http://cloudbase-ci.com/neutron/632479/3 : SUCCESS in 1h 53m 29s'}, {'account_id': 10267, 'date': '2019-02-05 04:26:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

> Oops, mis-click. Are we sure about breaking backwards compat here?
 > The "correct" fix would be for the client to use bulk create.

Not only create operation, concurrent delete/update of other security group rules belonging to a security group will also fail. So bulk create is not only the solution.

 > Though honestly, the really "correct" change would be to actually
 > CRUD on sg's and sg rule's separately, so we weren't dragging
 > around lists of child objects on every operation. But that ship has
 > sailed in api v2.
Can you please explain more on this?'}, {'account_id': 10267, 'date': '2019-02-05 09:52:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 26622, 'date': '2019-02-05 11:38:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Build succeeded.

- neutron http://cloudbase-ci.com/neutron/632479/3 : SUCCESS in 1h 45m 36s'}, {'account_id': 10267, 'date': '2019-02-05 15:39:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

> > Oops, mis-click. Are we sure about breaking backwards compat
 > here?
 > > The "correct" fix would be for the client to use bulk create.
 > 
 > Not only create operation, concurrent delete/update of other
 > security group rules belonging to a security group will also fail.
 > So bulk create is not only the solution.
 > 

The chances of bulk creation failure is high if there is simultaneous create/update/delete operation either on sg or sgr.

 > > Though honestly, the really "correct" change would be to actually
 > > CRUD on sg's and sg rule's separately, so we weren't dragging
 > > around lists of child objects on every operation. But that ship
 > has
 > > sailed in api v2.
 > Can you please explain more on this?'}, {'account_id': 27419, 'date': '2019-02-05 16:18:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 11975, 'date': '2019-02-05 17:22:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

I think that we can't do it like that for few reasons. First is that revision numbers are described already in docs that it will be changed on every change done on resource: https://developer.openstack.org/api-ref/network/v2/index.html?expanded=show-security-group-detail#revisions and in fact adding SG rule to SG is update of SG so its revision should be bumped.
Second thing is that this works in exactly same way for e.g. QoS policies and QoS rules now. So by merging this patch we would make our API not consistent here.

We need some other way to fix this performance issue unfortunately. We discussed some ideas today and Nate will investigate some other way how we can do it better :)"}, {'account_id': 11816, 'date': '2019-02-21 19:10:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

should this be abandoned now that I2fef298041c59a03dfd06912764973995b80690c has merged?'}, {'account_id': 1131, 'date': '2019-02-21 20:52:49.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

https://review.openstack.org/#/c/635671/ was a better fix'}]

[{'created': '2019-01-22 14:42:46.000000000', 'message': 'Remove revises_on_change from SecurityGroupRule

Because of this attribute, revision number in standardattribute table
updated for security group when trying to create security group rule.
When many simultaneous requests issued to creatse security groups rule
for the same security group, this update is failing sometimes and
the transaction is retried. Because of this we are seeing increase in
number of DB connections and API response taking huge time and some
times even failing. After removing this, agents are still able to
process and apply security group rules correctly.

I have tested on devstack setup with defaults for DB max_pool_size and
max_overflow and with 6 neutron api_workers and 6 keystone workers.
When I tried to create 300 security group rules for same security group,
without this patch, mysqld connections went to 280 and was using above
200 connections most of the time and max time taken for the API was
300 seconds (many API calls were taking 300 seconds and some calls were
failing). With this patch, DB connections went to 200 but came back to
70 soon and was remaining in 70s for the API calls. All calls were
succesful and also max response time taken was 30 seconds.

Change-Id: I822656f305fa08c590e2bfbc377cd60d1820ca90

commit_message:
Remove revises_on_change from SecurityGroupRule

Because of this attribute, revision number in standardattribute table
updated for security group when trying to create security group rule.
When many simultaneous requests issued to creatse security groups rule
for the same security group, this update is failing sometimes and
the transaction is retried. Because of this we are seeing increase in
number of DB connections and API response taking huge time and some
times even failing. After removing this, agents are still able to
process and apply security group rules correctly.

I have tested on devstack setup with defaults for DB max_pool_size and
max_overflow and with 6 neutron api_workers and 6 keystone workers.
When I tried to create 300 security group rules for same security group,
without this patch, mysqld connections went to 280 and was using above
200 connections most of the time and max time taken for the API was
300 seconds (many API calls were taking 300 seconds and some calls were
failing). With this patch, DB connections went to 200 but came back to
70 soon and was remaining in 70s for the API calls. All calls were
succesful and also max response time taken was 30 seconds.

Removing some tests which were added in below changes
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/303966/
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/409976/

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/634632/
Change-Id: I822656f305fa08c590e2bfbc377cd60d1820ca90

[{'created': '2019-02-14 10:40:26.000000000', 'message': "tox: Don't write byte code (maybe)

In tox versions after 3.0.0rc1 [1], setting the environment variable
PYTHONDONTWRITEBYTECODE will cause tox not to write .pyc files, which
means you don't have to delete them, which makes things faster.

In older tox versions, the env var is ignored.

If we bump the minimum tox version to something later than 3.0.0rc1, we
can remove the commands that find and remove .pyc files.

[1] https://github.com/tox-dev/tox/commit/336f4f6bd8b53223f940fc5cfc43b1bbd78d4699

Change-Id: I779a17afade78997ab084909a9e6a46b0f91f055
(cherry picked from commit 590a2b6bbf71294d187d7082cc302069797db029)
"}]
commit_message:
tox: Don't write byte code (maybe)

In tox versions after 3.0.0rc1 [1], setting the environment variable
PYTHONDONTWRITEBYTECODE will cause tox not to write .pyc files, which
means you don't have to delete them, which makes things faster.

In older tox versions, the env var is ignored.

If we bump the minimum tox version to something later than 3.0.0rc1, we
can remove the commands that find and remove .pyc files.

[1] https://github.com/tox-dev/tox/commit/336f4f6bd8b53223f940fc5cfc43b1bbd78d4699

Change-Id: I779a17afade78997ab084909a9e6a46b0f91f055
(cherry picked from commit 590a2b6bbf71294d187d7082cc302069797db029)

commit_message:
Deprecate docker config options

The docker_bip, docker_insecure_registries and docker_registry_mirror
have been deprecated. docker_bip will be removed in later versions.
docker_insecure_registries has been renamed to
container_insecure_regiestries. docker_registry_mirror has been renamed
to container_registry_mirror.

Change-Id: Ic39e665b241aed74347be5eaf24fb291035d5658
Related-Blueprint: podman-support

commit_message:
Fix node delete with lifecycle hook bug

Create copy of child node list and remove nodes from the original child
list if a node does not need to enter waiting lifecycle completion
because it is not found or not in ACTIVE state.

Change-Id: I04d57f4deb2f9f46aba1d9d4a566cb90dbe74d96
Closes-Bug: #1816677

commit_message:
WIP: move amphora glance image upload to an overcloud node

Since moving to containerized undercloud, the deployment does not work
with RPM based amphora installs since mistral is in a container. This
patch moves the amphora image management from running on the undercloud
node to running on the overcloud.

(needs bug report)

Change-Id: I410f8fa38bdd380cfa174f9c210a3f221ab3e804

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-02-19 19:54:52.000000000', 'message': 'Handle upper and lower case system uuids

We need to be able to handle when system uuids are upper or lower case
because newer versions of dmidecode have normalized to lower case. Users
who were on CentOS/RHEL 7.5 and older may have per-node customizations
with upper case which turn lowercase with an update to 7.6. This affects
hieradata customizations as well as os-net-config mapping files. This
change outputs both an upper and lowercase hieradata uuid file to handle
the both versions of the UUID. Additionally this change checks if
system-uuid is used in the os-net-config mapping and matches on either
upper or lower case.

Change-Id: I65f46056f8a908c60c99d1cee3738344a0bce6b7
Closes-Bug: #1816652
'}, {'created': '2019-02-19 19:56:05.000000000', 'message': 'Handle upper and lower case system uuids

We need to be able to handle when system uuids are upper or lower case
because newer versions of dmidecode have normalized to lower case. Users
who were on CentOS/RHEL 7.5 and older may have per-node customizations
with upper case which turn lowercase with an update to 7.6. This affects
hieradata customizations as well as os-net-config mapping files. This
change outputs both an upper and lowercase hieradata uuid file to handle
the both versions of the UUID. Additionally this change normalizes the
id comparison for os-net-config mappings to lower case.

Change-Id: I65f46056f8a908c60c99d1cee3738344a0bce6b7
Closes-Bug: #1816652
'}, {'created': '2019-02-19 19:59:01.000000000', 'message': 'Handle upper and lower case system uuids

We need to be able to handle when system uuids are upper or lower case
because newer versions of dmidecode have normalized to lower case. Users
who were on CentOS/RHEL 7.5 and older may have per-node customizations
with upper case which turn lowercase with an update to 7.6. This affects
hieradata customizations as well as os-net-config mapping files. This
change outputs both an upper and lowercase hieradata uuid file to handle
the both versions of the UUID. Additionally this change normalizes the
id comparison for os-net-config mappings to lower case.

Change-Id: I65f46056f8a908c60c99d1cee3738344a0bce6b7
Closes-Bug: #1816652
'}]
commit_message:
Handle upper and lower case system uuids

We need to be able to handle when system uuids are upper or lower case
because newer versions of dmidecode have normalized to lower case. Users
who were on CentOS/RHEL 7.5 and older may have per-node customizations
with upper case which turn lowercase with an update to 7.6. This affects
hieradata customizations as well as os-net-config mapping files. This
change outputs both an upper and lowercase hieradata uuid file to handle
the both versions of the UUID. Additionally this change normalizes the
id comparison for os-net-config mappings to lower case.

Change-Id: I65f46056f8a908c60c99d1cee3738344a0bce6b7
Closes-Bug: #1816652

commit_message:
Blacklist oslo.service 1.37.0

oslo.service 1.37.0 introduced[1] yappi 0.99 (recently added to g-r[2]) to
the requirements.txt. Unfortunately this version of yappi has a known
bug[3] that is causing job failures[4].

This patch will blacklist the 1.37.0 version of oslo.service.

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/release-announce/2019-February/ \
    006465.html
[2] https://github.com/openstack/requirements/commit/ \
    d9797f1dd667ad4bfea67bd6db1d2c016826a1e1
[3] https://github.com/sumerc/yappi/commit/ \
    778829f6f77928e4292e6a7dd4dfecf501f9a362
[4] http://logs.openstack.org/29/637929/2/check/octavia-v2-dsvm-scenario/ \
    4113e77/controller/logs/dib-build/amphora-x64-haproxy.qcow2_log.txt.gz \
    #_2019-02-19_17_23_37_112

Change-Id: Ic312f69b665b44f285fe08a026fec3e1ca5dc65b

should catch issues here before they are synchronised.

[{'created': '2019-02-21 10:20:04.000000000', 'message': "Avoid loading same service plugin more than once

In patch [1] requirement that only each service plugin
can be loaded only once was removed.
Unfortunatelly it is not possible that same service plugin
will be instantiate more than once because it may reqister some
callbacks or other things which can't be duplicated.

So this patch adds mechanism which will ensure that each service
plugin class is instantiate only once and reused if necessary.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/626561/

Closes-Bug: #1816771

Change-Id: Ie6e6cc1bbbe50ff7cfad4e8033e48711569ea020
"}]
commit_message:
Avoid loading same service plugin more than once

In patch [1] requirement that only each service plugin
can be loaded only once was removed.
Unfortunatelly it is not possible that same service plugin
will be instantiate more than once because it may reqister some
callbacks or other things which can't be duplicated.

So this patch adds mechanism which will ensure that each service
plugin class is instantiate only once and reused if necessary.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/626561/

Closes-Bug: #1816771

Change-Id: Ie6e6cc1bbbe50ff7cfad4e8033e48711569ea020

[{'created': '2019-02-19 18:02:13.000000000', 'message': "Include .inc files in doc8 linting

This issue was recently seen in cinder when the gate failed
to detect trailing whitespaces in '.inc' files.
As seen, manila was also prone to such issues but thankfully
no error was found in '.inc' after running against doc8.
It still seems important to include it in the testing to avoid
future similar issues.

Change-Id: Ie1fd4ddb4448c05559a31098302f84367fe6ed52
"}]
commit_message:
Include .inc files in doc8 linting

This issue was recently seen in cinder when the gate failed
to detect trailing whitespaces in '.inc' files.
As seen, manila was also prone to such issues but thankfully
no error was found in '.inc' after running against doc8.
It still seems important to include it in the testing to avoid
future similar issues.

Change-Id: Ie1fd4ddb4448c05559a31098302f84367fe6ed52

commit_message:
Refuse secure erase if ATA command does not work

Adds dependency upon smartmontools's binary smartctl to
query the block devices via ATA mode which fails on pass-thru
buses such as ATA over SCSI and ATA over USB, in an effort
to prevent the initiation of ATA secure erase with one
of these interfaces in place which may render the disk
unreachable after security options are enabled for
ATA Secure Erase or upon the Secure Erase command being
sent to the Hard Disk.

Conflicts:
	Dockerfile

Change-Id: I7635a197eb000650e919fac386b38ac15ef17041
Story: #2002546
Task: #22109
Depends-On: Ibbfd168844524d91927bdd6e67d973e0bd519bf2
(cherry picked from commit aef703b87995cc33087c972492c8b8723a76677e)

commit_message:
Try to unlock failed device before proceeding

When a hard error has occured with secure erase,
we should attempt an unlock of the device becuase
the current mode can prevent disk IO. This may upset
some things like raid controllers even if they are
in a pass-through mode.

Change-Id: I32e1d962fbbb4a305d5dbebea92ac48ebd9b67ca
Story: #2002546
Task: #22107
(cherry picked from commit 0f7b5a0896cf1b3080b7679278ff97a8dff0be80)

subject: cinder.conf: add [nova] section, override interface defaults
messages: [{'account_id': 2463, 'date': '2019-02-20 16:33:23.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 7353, 'date': '2019-02-20 16:38:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 25023, 'date': '2019-02-21 16:31:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-02-20 16:33:23.000000000', 'message': 'cinder.conf: add [nova] section, override interface defaults

To the best of my knowledge, the [nova] section in cinder.conf
is only ever used if the Cinder scheduler is acting as a Nova client
when the operator has enabled the InstanceLocalityFilter.

Per https://docs.openstack.org/cinder/latest/configuration/block-storage/samples/cinder.conf.html,
Cinder defaults to using the public Nova endpoint when using the
Nova API. This is contrary to OSA precedent, where services
normally use internal endpoints for service-to-service API requests.

When enabling the InstanceLocalityFilter in combination with Cinder
talking to the public Nova endpoint, this can create a very confusing
situation, particularly in pre-production clusters: if the public
endpoint has a self-signed SSL certificate, and Cinder is not
explicitly configured not to verify certificates, then this creates
a whole load of connection errors.

Thus, in order to follow POLA, configure the [nova] section to use
the internal endpoint, and (in case the internal endpoint does
use HTTPS) honor the keystone_service_internaluri_insecure setting,
as for other services.

Change-Id: Ie31a7e2917a188027db49ac51e6a77ee39a9abf0
(cherry picked from commit 8c436038e383122490bde41543f0a57421504638)
'}]
commit_message:
cinder.conf: add [nova] section, override interface defaults

To the best of my knowledge, the [nova] section in cinder.conf
is only ever used if the Cinder scheduler is acting as a Nova client
when the operator has enabled the InstanceLocalityFilter.

Per https://docs.openstack.org/cinder/latest/configuration/block-storage/samples/cinder.conf.html,
Cinder defaults to using the public Nova endpoint when using the
Nova API. This is contrary to OSA precedent, where services
normally use internal endpoints for service-to-service API requests.

When enabling the InstanceLocalityFilter in combination with Cinder
talking to the public Nova endpoint, this can create a very confusing
situation, particularly in pre-production clusters: if the public
endpoint has a self-signed SSL certificate, and Cinder is not
explicitly configured not to verify certificates, then this creates
a whole load of connection errors.

Thus, in order to follow POLA, configure the [nova] section to use
the internal endpoint, and (in case the internal endpoint does
use HTTPS) honor the keystone_service_internaluri_insecure setting,
as for other services.

Change-Id: Ie31a7e2917a188027db49ac51e6a77ee39a9abf0
(cherry picked from commit 8c436038e383122490bde41543f0a57421504638)

normally use internal endpoints for service-to-service API requests.

When enabling the InstanceLocalityFilter in combination with Cinder

Thus, in order to follow POLA, configure the [nova] section to use
the internal endpoint, and (in case the internal endpoint does
use HTTPS) honor the keystone_service_internaluri_insecure setting,

Change-Id: Ie31a7e2917a188027db49ac51e6a77ee39a9abf0
(cherry picked from commit 8c436038e383122490bde41543f0a57421504638)

commit_message:
cinder.conf: add [nova] section, override interface defaults

To the best of my knowledge, the [nova] section in cinder.conf
is only ever used if the Cinder scheduler is acting as a Nova client
when the operator has enabled the InstanceLocalityFilter.

Per https://docs.openstack.org/cinder/latest/configuration/block-storage/samples/cinder.conf.html,
Cinder defaults to using the public Nova endpoint when using the
Nova API. This is contrary to OSA precedent, where services
normally use internal endpoints for service-to-service API requests.

When enabling the InstanceLocalityFilter in combination with Cinder
talking to the public Nova endpoint, this can create a very confusing
situation, particularly in pre-production clusters: if the public
endpoint has a self-signed SSL certificate, and Cinder is not
explicitly configured not to verify certificates, then this creates
a whole load of connection errors.

Thus, in order to follow POLA, configure the [nova] section to use
the internal endpoint, and (in case the internal endpoint does
use HTTPS) honor the keystone_service_internaluri_insecure setting,
as for other services.

Change-Id: Ie31a7e2917a188027db49ac51e6a77ee39a9abf0
(cherry picked from commit 8c436038e383122490bde41543f0a57421504638)

commit_message:
Use correct certificate when ``os-public-hostname`` configration option is set

Note that this is a short term kludge/fix, on the long term
we should ditch the charm specific ApacheSSLContext and use
the common one from charm-helpers with an adapted Apache
config inspired from the ``openstack_https_fronted`` template

Change-Id: I74c17113f431c4c21f638be6abffaeeb693f1462
Closes-Bug: #1816621

commit_message:
Manage Compute services in nova manual typos

 Command openstack compute service set typos
  As IS :  --disable --disable-reason trial log nova nova-compute
  To Be :  --disable --disable-reason "trial log" nova nova-compute

Related Bugs:#1815167

Change-Id: Ibfe5500c4fbac91e4f5bec492d7ad89f69957f2a

commit_message:
Correct examples in "Manage Compute services" documentation

* "compute service set" command requires a host, not a zone
* the --disable-reason flag's argument has to be quoted

Change-Id: Iaf58d702b1619a66f97553cf2e47eb8c85166bf6

commit_message:
Add heat_user_pip_packages variable

With this variable, users would be able to extend
the list of pip packages in case of needing an
extra pip package.

Currently if we need an extra pip package we need
to override the existing list.

Change-Id: I9aea9f42c476ff3c6f2355a0afb21be4eea57b69

commit_message:
Modify api and rpc default number of workers

- Limit number of api workers to roughly using half of system
  RAM. Spawning a bunch, just to have the OOM killer nuke them
  regularly is not useful.
- Bump the rpc_workers default to half of the api_workers.
  A default of 1 falls behind on any reasonably sized node.

Change-Id: I8b84a359f83133014b3d4414aafc10e6b7c6a876
Closes-bug: #1815629

commit_message:
Add horizon_user_pip_packages variable

With this variable, users would be able to extend
the list of pip packages in case of needing an
extra pip package.

Currently if we need an extra pip package we need
to override the existing list.

Change-Id: I9b41af83b473a19a3097e4754c17928b23b968d5

[{'created': '2019-02-18 15:37:46.000000000', 'message': "Add IPv6 default route to OVN Logical Router

Prior to this patch, only IPv4 subnets were accounted to install
static routes on Logical Routers when setting a external gateway.
This is a problem if the public network has an IPv6 subnet as
instances won't get a default route.

Change-Id: I1cb4cd3dd2bf3be1e0beb4f2cc89a89fcf803f70
Closes-Bug: #1808753
Signed-off-by: Daniel Alvarez <dalvarez@redhat.com>
(cherry picked from commit ed5f25bb37de68688930d80dae7eb0cf447de70c)
"}]
commit_message:
Add IPv6 default route to OVN Logical Router

Prior to this patch, only IPv4 subnets were accounted to install
static routes on Logical Routers when setting a external gateway.
This is a problem if the public network has an IPv6 subnet as
instances won't get a default route.

Change-Id: I1cb4cd3dd2bf3be1e0beb4f2cc89a89fcf803f70
Closes-Bug: #1808753
Signed-off-by: Daniel Alvarez <dalvarez@redhat.com>
(cherry picked from commit ed5f25bb37de68688930d80dae7eb0cf447de70c)

commit_message:
Add keystone_user_pip_packages variable

With this variable, users would be able to extend
the list of pip packages in case of needing an
extra pip package.

Currently if we need an extra pip package we need
to override the existing list.

Change-Id: If2a01309f37c585cdd6a7d8d1f6d893e0707626a

commit_message:
VMAX Driver - VMAX OS Upgrade Bug

Workload support was dropped in ucode 5978. If a VMAX All Flash
array is upgraded to 5978 or greater and existing volume types
leveraged workload e.g. DSS, DSS_REP, OLTP and OLTP_REP,
attaching and detaching will no longer work and the volume type
will be unusable.

Change-Id: I0ad0c530c93a9494e1a3048e557360b38c4a125b
Closes-Bug: #1790141
(cherry picked from commit 546faf0cd5fa86dadec3a04765e5592f1a1305ab)

commit_message:
Fix disable and re-enable of PKI secrets engine

Several flags were not being managed properly, and certs were not being
re-issued when PKI was re-enabled.

Conflicts:
  src/actions/actions.py
    Conflicts in pload_signed_csr() and generate_root_ca() from
    (8f490507bce678c9a2d79bff5efb04a852f19118) The order of the patches
    changed which brings small conflicts

Closes-Bug: #1813180
Change-Id: Ifac75028897d22c277750a747f79d4dfedb4f987
(cherry picked from commit 3b947315200f295651eed07f5ca80a65abca459e)

commit_message:
Fix unbound "mac" variable

There's a DEBUG trace which is using a non existent variable in
that scope and that caused a failure when DEBUG level was enabled.

commit_message:
Allow multiple config files for neutron plugin

There are times a third party SDN may require more than one
configuration file for a neutron-plugin. For example:
plugins/ml2/ml2_conf.ini and plugins/vendor/vendor.ini.

Make the resource map handle a list of configuration files when
configured in the neutron-plugin.

Change-Id: I27e193be1ede492440d9cf762b3447e09cdce0f3

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-10-03 02:36:20.000000000', 'message': 'Fix aggregate members in nested alloc candidates

When placement picks up allocation candidates, the aggregates of
nested providers were assumed as the same as root providers. This
means that the `GET /allocation_candidates API` ignored the
aggregates on the nested providers. This could result in the lack
of allocation candidates when an aggregate is on a nested provider
but the aggregate is not on its root provider and the aggregate is
specified in the API by the `member_of` query parameter.

This patch fixes the bug changing it to consider the aggregates
not only on root rps but also on the nested rp itself and adds
a release note for this.

This is a backport from the following two patches on master of the
extracted placement project.

  - https://review.openstack.org/#/c/602638
  - https://review.openstack.org/#/c/602639

Change-Id: I28876cfbfaed4e2330df08ab0d1b09d19647b2a7
Closes-Bug: #1792503
'}, {'created': '2018-10-09 10:02:37.000000000', 'message': 'Add alloc cands test with nested and aggregates

When placement picks up allocation candidates, the aggregates of
nested providers are assumed as the same as root providers. This
means it ignores the aggregates of the nested provider itself.
This could result in the lack of allocation candidates when an
aggregate on a nested provider but not on the root has been
specified in the `member_of` query parameter.

This patch adds test cases for the bug. The fix is done in a
follow up.

This is a backport from the following patch on master of the
extracted placement project.

  - https://review.openstack.org/#/c/602638

Change-Id: I28876cfbfaed4e2330df08ab0d1b09d19647b2a7
Closes-Bug: #1792503
'}]
commit_message:
Add alloc cands test with nested and aggregates

When placement picks up allocation candidates, the aggregates of
nested providers are assumed as the same as root providers. This
means it ignores the aggregates of the nested provider itself.
This could result in the lack of allocation candidates when an
aggregate on a nested provider but not on the root has been
specified in the `member_of` query parameter.

This patch adds test cases for the bug. The fix is done in a
follow up.

This is a backport from the following patch on master of the
extracted placement project.

  - https://review.openstack.org/#/c/602638

Change-Id: I28876cfbfaed4e2330df08ab0d1b09d19647b2a7
Closes-Bug: #1792503

[{'account_id': 25625, 'date': '2018-10-09 10:02:37.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-10-15 22:54:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Do we care about this in nova in rocky? We don't even support scheduling to nested resources in rocky do we?"}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-10-15 22:54:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Or this isn't about nova, it's about placement?"}, {'account_id': 25625, 'date': '2018-10-16 00:36:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> We don't even support scheduling to nested resources in rocky do we?
> Or this isn't about nova, it's about placement?

We don't. Nova doesn't care. It's just about placement. 

See https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/nova-ptg-stein L177.

This bug was reported by Eric orally in the PTG and we agreed to fix this bug in extracted placement and backport it to stable/rocky. And later when I reproduced the bug with test codes, it turned out that the bug was not that serious. Namely, the reported bug in PTG was "The aggregate on root doesn't span the whole tree", while the actual bug was "The aggregate on root does span the whole tree *overwriting* the aggregate on the child. But we don't want to remove the original aggregate on the child."

So, now we might have less motivation to backport this. But since it is weird that the behavior between rocky and stein is different, I'd like to backport this.'}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2019-01-08 22:02:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

This has not been properly cherry-picked. Please add the cherry-pick footer to the commit message to link things (either through the Gerrit Cherry Pick button or via "git cherry-pick -x <sha> on the command line). If there is some reason it could not be backported following normal practice, please note the reason for that in the commit message.'}, {'account_id': 10135, 'date': '2019-02-12 12:56:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

> This has not been properly cherry-picked. Please add the
 > cherry-pick footer to the commit message to link things (either
 > through the Gerrit Cherry Pick button or via "git cherry-pick -x
 > <sha> on the command line). If there is some reason it could not be
 > backported following normal practice, please note the reason for
 > that in the commit message.

So this has come across from openstack/placement, I know the Placement code within openstack/nova on master is frozen for new features and API changes but I had assumed it was still open for targeted bugfixes like this. Can we land this there first and then backport?'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-02-21 16:30:38.000000000', 'content': "Abandoned

I'm going to abandon this since as far as I'm aware nothing is using nested providers in stable/rocky (nova isn't) so I think until this is needed by someone we don't need to backport it. I'm abandoning to clean up the nova stable/rocky review queue."}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-10-09 10:02:37.000000000', 'message': 'Fix aggregate members in nested alloc candidates

When placement picks up allocation candidates, the aggregates of
nested providers were assumed as the same as root providers. This
means that the `GET /allocation_candidates API` ignored the
aggregates on the nested providers. This could result in the lack
of allocation candidates when an aggregate is on a nested provider
but the aggregate is not on its root provider and the aggregate is
specified in the API by the `member_of` query parameter.

This patch fixes the bug changing it to consider the aggregates
not only on root rps but also on the nested rp itself and adds
a release note for this.

This is a backport from the following patch on master of the
extracted placement project.

  - https://review.openstack.org/#/c/602639

Change-Id: Ib6fd2899340679421416801f7a1f72ce4ded884b
Closes-Bug: #1792503
'}]
commit_message:
Fix aggregate members in nested alloc candidates

When placement picks up allocation candidates, the aggregates of
nested providers were assumed as the same as root providers. This
means that the `GET /allocation_candidates API` ignored the
aggregates on the nested providers. This could result in the lack
of allocation candidates when an aggregate is on a nested provider
but the aggregate is not on its root provider and the aggregate is
specified in the API by the `member_of` query parameter.

This patch fixes the bug changing it to consider the aggregates
not only on root rps but also on the nested rp itself and adds
a release note for this.

This is a backport from the following patch on master of the
extracted placement project.

  - https://review.openstack.org/#/c/602639

Change-Id: Ib6fd2899340679421416801f7a1f72ce4ded884b
Closes-Bug: #1792503

commit_message:
Fix issue with crontab enablement

The token flush and token rotate crontabs are re-written when the
leader unit changes inline with Juju leadership management.

Align contexts used to generate crontabs with Juju leadership
status, rather than corosync/pacemaker.

Correct use of OpenStackCompareReleases to ensure that releases
between ocata and queens don't automatically enable fernet
token behaviour.

Change-Id: I6db8d006ceac7b61e69f547682c5a49d876cfec6
Closes-Bug: 1816807

[{'created': '2019-02-20 15:37:08.000000000', 'message': "Correct key name for PKI backend TTL

Switch max-lease-ttl -> max_lease_ttl inline with Vault API
docs to ensure that certs can be issued for more than 30 days.

Existing deployments with PKI enabled will be re-tuned to
set max_lease_ttl to 10 years, correcting any existing PKI
enablement.

Certificates must be re-issued to use the TTL as provided
during upload of the signed CSR for an Intermediate certificate.

For deploys using the internally signed Root CA, the root
CA must be re-generated using the 'disable-pki' and
'generate-root-ca' actions.

commit_message:
Correct key name for PKI backend TTL

Switch max-lease-ttl -> max_lease_ttl inline with Vault API
docs to ensure that certs can be issued for more than 30 days.

Existing deployments with PKI enabled will be re-tuned to
set max_lease_ttl to 10 years, correcting any existing PKI
enablement.

Certificates must be re-issued to use the TTL as provided
during upload of the signed CSR for an Intermediate certificate.

For deploys using the internally signed Root CA, the root
CA must be re-generated using the 'disable-pki' and
'generate-root-ca' actions.

Change-Id: I6a771090e320404c605d2170c7915c3c22a3ea2c
Closes-Bug: 1788945
(cherry picked from commit 6f043bb7ca8710dd7c1746297b6f98f743c3499a)

commit_message:
Improve Vault startup handling

The `@when_file_changed` decorator is not considered reliable.
Additionally, the way it was being used led to a race condition where
the Vault service might never get started. This also detects and reports
in a better way if Vault fails to start.

Conflicts:
  unit_tests/test_reactive_vault_handlers.py
    A test_tune_pki_backend() test was introduced by
    (6f043bb7ca8710dd7c1746297b6f98f743c3499a). But because of the
    race condition in CI I had to change the order of the patches and
    put that one at the bottom.

Change-Id: If6153377cd516ed8121e09da627905036128a6ec
(cherry picked from commit 102b222fcec550d7b30eb10583887fa212c61eff)

commit_message:
API microversion 2.69: Handles Down Cells

This patch explicitly points out the change needed while
forming the detailed lists for embedded flavor information.
In those cases where the server response for nova list
has the flavor key missing for the instances in the down cell,
the servers will be skipped.

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/591657/

Related to blueprint handling-down-cell

Change-Id: I007d9a68309b0d3aa85a4edf5026043154d4f42a

commit_message:
Make Server.networks use a predictable sort order

This changes the Server.networks property method to return
an OrderedDict where the keys (network labels) are sorted
which will allow for a predictable sort order on the resulting
networks attached to a Server resource.

This affects the output of "nova list" and "nova show" commands
so a simple release note is added to mention the change.

Change-Id: I2e9b3c6a256509c045966035da24d58628f1b33b

commit_message:
Implement new option: enable_new_services

This change implements a new option in config.yaml that allows
services to come up disabled and be manually enabled later.

Change-Id: I345b56e347b63650ee3df07773ccb2e333610355
Closes-Bug: #1758776

commit_message:
Make relative import py2/3 compatible

9e7ee5dd5c399fb6edeee771d9027846c4bdd1b6 made the import work in
unit tests, but not when run in actual use. This change makes the
relative import explicit which will work in both versions and both
environments.


Change-Id: If2cf598bf062452f78c717b178cb3a294df08a8a

subject: Add co-owned library exception to feature freeze policy
messages:
[{'account_id': 6928, 'date': '2019-02-18 17:06:57.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 6928, 'date': '2019-02-18 21:55:18.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Workflow-1

The more I look at this, the more I have second thoughts. Both my cited examples (pycadf and castellan) are used in non-client libraries themselves, which means the reasoning behind a separate Oslo feature freeze _does_ apply to them. Plus, as Colleen pointed out on the list, as written this is wrong since it includes things like oslo.policy that we definitely do want to freeze early.

So maybe we don't want to do this after all. I'll leave the spec open for a bit for discussion, but if no one comes up with a compelling reason to add another exception I'll just abandon it and leave the policy as-is."}, {'account_id': 6928, 'date': '2019-02-21 16:08:32.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-02-18 17:06:57.000000000', 'message': "Add co-owned library exception to feature freeze policy

Co-owned libraries generally function a bit differently from the
usual oslo.* libraries. Specifically, they are non-client libraries
and should observe the regular feature freeze for that type of library.
There isn't a need for the additional adoption time for features in
these libraries so the reasoning behind the Oslo feature freeze date
doesn't apply.

This change adds an exception to the feature freeze policy to reflect
the above logic.

Change-Id: Iabe22dca0a913d942b9f325e93630f6fd4c26fb7
"}]
commit_message:
Add co-owned library exception to feature freeze policy

Co-owned libraries generally function a bit differently from the
usual oslo.* libraries. Specifically, they are non-client libraries
and should observe the regular feature freeze for that type of library.
There isn't a need for the additional adoption time for features in
these libraries so the reasoning behind the Oslo feature freeze date
doesn't apply.

This change adds an exception to the feature freeze policy to reflect
the above logic.

Change-Id: Iabe22dca0a913d942b9f325e93630f6fd4c26fb7

image-serve: redirect root to /v2

Nobody needs to see the default apache page, let's just redirect to v2
so operators aren't confused.

commit_message:
Create deployment/deprecated directory

It's not easy to find which services are deprecated, so let's create a
directory: deployment/deprecated and put the services in there.

This patch:
- creates the directory and a README
- moves already deprecated services into that directory
- update all references to these services to point to the right files

Change-Id: Id6c927d9c0db024875032f04228047d029c0696d

commit_message:
FFWD: Introduce workaround for neutron cisco plugin

Neutron cisco plugin package update is not triggered by update of
neutron package. If this plugin is enabled the neutron db sync
will fail unless we update python-networking-cisco package.

Change-Id: I3ac3d9baf51c7a9e13d20985fbe47cd5404eb88d
Resolves: rhbz#1652209
Closes-bug: #1804494
(cherry picked from commit 4e8c2faf36d94257760b5d07195e1d90fefbc2c4)

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-02-21 09:12:29.000000000', 'message': 'rework ATA secure erase

hdparm versions prior to 9.51 interpret the value, NULL, as a
password with string value: "NULL".

Example output of hdparm with NULL password:

    [root@localhost ~]# hdparm --user-master u --security-unlock NULL /dev/sda
    security_password="NULL"

    /dev/sda:
    Issuing SECURITY_UNLOCK command, password="NULL", user=user
    SECURITY_UNLOCK: Input/output error

Example output of hdparm with "" as password:

    [root@localhost ~]# hdparm --user-master u --security-unlock "" /dev/sda
    security_password=""

    /dev/sda:
     Issuing SECURITY_UNLOCK command, password="", user=user

Note the values of security_password in the output above. The output
was observed on a CentOS 7 system, which ships hdparm 9.43 in the
offical repositories.

This change attempts to unlock the drive with the empty string if an
unlock with NULL was unsucessful.

Issuing a security-unlock will cause a state transition from SEC4
(security enabled, locked, not frozen) to SEC5 (security enabled,
unlocked, not frozen). In order to check that a password unlock attempt
was successful it makes sense to check that the drive is in the unlocked
state (a necessary condition for SEC5). Only after all unlock attempts
fail, do we consider the drive out of our control.

The conditions to check the drive is in the right state have been
adjusted to ensure that the drive is in the SEC5 state prior to issuing
a secure erase. Previously, on the "recovery from previous fail" path,
the security state was asserted to be "not enabled" after an unlock -
this could never have been the case.

A good overview of the ATA security states can be found here:

  http://www.admin-magazine.com/Archive/2014/19/Using-the-ATA-security-features-of-modern-hard-disks-and-SSDs

Change-Id: Ic24b706a04ff6c08d750b9e3d79eb79eab2952ad
Story: 2001762
Task: 12161
Story: 2001763
Task: 12162
(cherry picked from commit aaf76e2cfb88c6cae50c8b46c65edce0a30e6a8f)
'}]
commit_message:
rework ATA secure erase

hdparm versions prior to 9.51 interpret the value, NULL, as a
password with string value: "NULL".

Example output of hdparm with NULL password:

    [root@localhost ~]# hdparm --user-master u --security-unlock NULL /dev/sda
    security_password="NULL"

    /dev/sda:
    Issuing SECURITY_UNLOCK command, password="NULL", user=user
    SECURITY_UNLOCK: Input/output error

Example output of hdparm with "" as password:

    [root@localhost ~]# hdparm --user-master u --security-unlock "" /dev/sda
    security_password=""

    /dev/sda:
     Issuing SECURITY_UNLOCK command, password="", user=user

Note the values of security_password in the output above. The output
was observed on a CentOS 7 system, which ships hdparm 9.43 in the
offical repositories.

This change attempts to unlock the drive with the empty string if an
unlock with NULL was unsucessful.

Issuing a security-unlock will cause a state transition from SEC4
(security enabled, locked, not frozen) to SEC5 (security enabled,
unlocked, not frozen). In order to check that a password unlock attempt
was successful it makes sense to check that the drive is in the unlocked
state (a necessary condition for SEC5). Only after all unlock attempts
fail, do we consider the drive out of our control.

The conditions to check the drive is in the right state have been
adjusted to ensure that the drive is in the SEC5 state prior to issuing
a secure erase. Previously, on the "recovery from previous fail" path,
the security state was asserted to be "not enabled" after an unlock -
this could never have been the case.

A good overview of the ATA security states can be found here:

  http://www.admin-magazine.com/Archive/2014/19/Using-the-ATA-security-features-of-modern-hard-disks-and-SSDs

Change-Id: Ic24b706a04ff6c08d750b9e3d79eb79eab2952ad
Story: 2001762
Task: 12161
Story: 2001763
Task: 12162
(cherry picked from commit aaf76e2cfb88c6cae50c8b46c65edce0a30e6a8f)

commit_message:
Add volume-group snapshot for admin panel

This commit allow admin to list/show and delete volume-group snapshots
using horizon dashboard.

Partially-Implements blueprint cinder-generic-volume-groups

Change-Id: If00d156a7a56ed699425b35ac60314c3a8cd049c

commit_message:
[WIP] Build tinyipa with python3

The patch updates ``buildreqs.lst`` and ``finalreqs.lst`` to
include python3.tcz and python3-dev.tcz. Patch also updates
build scripts to switch to python3.

Change-Id: Ib4c42985a19205528a0a84224d5532d329fc8ddb

commit_message:
Native Zuul v3 dashboard-integration test

- create a native Zuul v3 job, and move it to experimental
  until it works;
- install libav-utils on dpkg systems and enable the capture
  of the video;
- adapt to the changes in OverviewPage:
  * go_to_system_flavorspage -> go_to_admin_compute_flavorspage
  * go_to_compute_imagespage -> go_to_project_compute_imagespage

The job is failing right now, but apart the increased running time,
at least the tests are now executed.

Story: 2001686
Task: 8662

Change-Id: I311203779bd3e6c6660cfe1b84e89c7dc0825c98

(5 comments)

i think the if elif else formulation is fine.

i would like to include a section in our docs on OVO versioning if we could as well.

e.g. things like always call self.obj_make_compatible after first donwleveling field in the current object. or self.obj_make_compatible shoudl always be called once and only one in each path through a local implementation of obj_make_compatible.

i think looking at the code following this change that will be obvios from context but it wont hurt to have it written down somewhare.

an explanation on when to use obj_relationships would also be welcome
but ya i would like to hear what others think.'}, {'account_id': 25733, 'date': '2019-01-16 13:40:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Note to reviewers
I've tried to codify (with example) the reasoning behind the structure in this doc review on o.vo:
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/632321/

It might be better to discuss the general case over there, and the specifics in this review. Note that I have no strong opinions on style, as long as it's functional and consistent I'm happy (i.e. don't depend on me for good style).

Change-Id: Ib7b0cca596c0cad8095ef18243b94ada2587d1cd
'}, {'created': '2019-01-15 15:36:11.000000000', 'message': 'Clean up versioned object backlevelling code

The backlevelling code for the VIF objects have a number of sharp edges.
This commit changes the layout of the obj_make_compatible methods to conform
to the following pattern:

  # For the following version history:
  # Version 1.0: Initial Release
  # Version 1.1: Added member_one_one
  # Version 1.2: Base Class version increased to 1.1 from 1.0
  # Version 1.3: Added member_one_three
  # Version 1.4: Base Class version increased to 1.2 from 1.1

  0. use versionutils to calculate target_tuple
  1. Remove added members from the primitive:
     - if target_tuple < (1, 1) and 'member_one_one' in primitive:
           del primitive['member_one_one']
     - if target_tuple < (1, 3) and 'member_one_three' in primitive:
           del primitive['member_one_three']
  2. Call the parent method explicitly when the parent class caused a version
     bump in this object:
     - if target_tuple < (1, 2):
           super(MyClass, self).obj_make_compatible(primitive, "1.0")
     - elif target_tuple < (1, 4):
           super(MyClass, self).obj_make_compatible(primitive, "1.1")
  3. Finally, if the parent class did not cause a version bump, call it
     with the unchanged parameters:
     - else:
           super(MyClass, self).obj_make_compatible(primitive, target_version)

Change-Id: Ib7b0cca596c0cad8095ef18243b94ada2587d1cd
Signed-off-by: Jan Gutter <jan.gutter@netronome.com>
blueprint: generic-os-vif-offloads

'}, {'created': '2019-02-19 14:48:57.000000000', 'message': "Clean up versioned object backlevelling code

The backlevelling code for the VIF objects have a number of sharp edges.
This commit changes the layout of the obj_make_compatible methods to conform
to a fixed pattern.

Given the following version history:

 # Version 1.0: Initial Release based on ParentClass 1.0
 # Version 1.1: Added member_one_one
 # Version 1.2: ParentClass version increased to 1.1 from 1.0
 # Version 1.3: Added member_one_three
 # Version 1.4: ParentClass version increased to 1.2 from 1.1
 # Version 1.5: Added member_one_five

Use the following pattern for obj_make_compatible():

 0. use versionutils to calculate target_version

 1. Remove added members from the primitive in reverse order:
    - if target_version < (1, 5) and 'member_one_five' in primitive:
          del primitive['member_one_five']
    - if target_version < (1, 3) and 'member_one_three' in primitive:
          del primitive['member_one_three']
    - if target_version < (1, 1) and 'member_one_one' in primitive:
          del primitive['member_one_one']

 2. Call the parent method explicitly when the parent class caused a version
    bump in this object, in the following if/elif tree:
    - if target_version < (1, 2):
          super(MyClass, self).obj_make_compatible(primitive, '1.0')
    - elif target_version < (1, 4):
          super(MyClass, self).obj_make_compatible(primitive, '1.1')

 3. Finally, if target_version is recent enough, call the parent method with
    the current version of the parent class:
    - else:
          super(MyClass, self).obj_make_compatible(primitive, '1.2')

This pattern has been documented in: https://review.openstack.org/632321/

Change-Id: Ib7b0cca596c0cad8095ef18243b94ada2587d1cd
Signed-off-by: Jan Gutter <jan.gutter@netronome.com>

commit_message:
Clean up versioned object backlevelling code

The backlevelling code for the VIF objects have a number of sharp edges.
This commit changes the layout of the obj_make_compatible methods to conform
to a fixed pattern.

Given the following version history:

 # Version 1.0: Initial Release based on ParentClass 1.0
 # Version 1.1: Added member_one_one
 # Version 1.2: ParentClass version increased to 1.1 from 1.0
 # Version 1.3: Added member_one_three
 # Version 1.4: ParentClass version increased to 1.2 from 1.1
 # Version 1.5: Added member_one_five

Use the following pattern for obj_make_compatible():

 0. use versionutils to calculate target_version

 1. Remove added members from the primitive in reverse order:
    - if target_version < (1, 5) and 'member_one_five' in primitive:
          del primitive['member_one_five']
    - if target_version < (1, 3) and 'member_one_three' in primitive:
          del primitive['member_one_three']
    - if target_version < (1, 1) and 'member_one_one' in primitive:
          del primitive['member_one_one']

 2. Call the parent method explicitly when the parent class caused a version
    bump in this object, in the following if/elif tree:
    - if target_version < (1, 2):
          super(MyClass, self).obj_make_compatible(primitive, '1.0')
    - elif target_version < (1, 4):
          super(MyClass, self).obj_make_compatible(primitive, '1.1')

 3. Finally, if target_version is recent enough, call the parent method with
    the current version of the parent class:
    - else:
          super(MyClass, self).obj_make_compatible(primitive, '1.2')

This pattern has been documented in: https://review.openstack.org/632321/

Change-Id: Ib7b0cca596c0cad8095ef18243b94ada2587d1cd
Signed-off-by: Jan Gutter <jan.gutter@netronome.com>
blueprint: generic-os-vif-offloads

commit_message:
Remove vgc-cluster

Remvoe vgc-cluster command from rootwrap filers.

Change-Id: I4178f8273fd50b947e3bbaabc9628f8b05fc5b31
Signed-off-by: Charles Short <chucks@redhat.com>

subject: Switch tempest-slow to be run on python 3

commit_message:
Switch tempest-slow to be run on python 3

This patch switches tempest-slow to new
tempest-slow-py3 job.

For coverage of tempest-slow tests on py2,
Tempest check pipeline will continue running
this job on check pipeline. As this tempest-slow
job is not from integrated gate template, it is
ok to run only py3 job on project side.

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/633983
Change-Id: I4f305429ec2baac8556b59e72292f06524370c17

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-02-07 23:02:55.000000000', 'message': "Clarify cache_on_issue configuration option help text

The help text for ``keystone.conf [token] cache_on_issue`` claimed
that it only cached tokens if global caching was enabled through
oslo.cache and if ``keystone.conf [token] caching = True``. However,
the actual implementation doesn't check if ``keystone.conf [token]
caching = True`` at all. Even if token caching is disabled, tokens will
be cached when they are issued.

This commit updates the help text of the cache_on_issue configuration
option to accurately describe what it does.

We should consider if we want this to be the behavior we want or if
keystone should not cache_on_issue if token caching is disabled.

Change-Id: I1e1117deabadaba26ea8e833a06180529e1e0a4b
"}, {'created': '2019-02-07 23:03:16.000000000', 'message': "Clarify cache_on_issue configuration option help text
