oslo.cache and if ``keystone.conf [token] caching = True``. However,
the actual implementation doesn't check if ``keystone.conf [token]
caching = True`` at all. Even if token caching is disabled, tokens will
be cached when they are issued.

This commit updates the help text of the cache_on_issue configuration
option to accurately describe what it does.

We should consider if we want this to be the behavior we want or if
keystone should not cache_on_issue if token caching is disabled.

Change-Id: I1e1117deabadaba26ea8e833a06180529e1e0a4b
"}, {'created': '2019-02-18 17:15:18.000000000', 'message': "Deprecate cache_on_issue configuration option

commit_message:
Deprecate cache_on_issue configuration option

Keystone already supports a global caching toggle and an option to
configure token caching explicitly. Having a third option to enable
pre-cached tokens is redundant, creates unnecessary complexity that
bleeds through to operators, and causes weird behaviors if token
caching is disabled and pre-caching is not.

This commit deprecates the cache_on_issue configuration option in
favor of just using ``keystone.conf [token] caching`` option instead.
This commit also attempts to clarify the help text so that it
describes the relationship between the various caching options, even
if it is short-lived.

The help text for ``keystone.conf [token] cache_on_issue`` claimed
that it only cached tokens if global caching was enabled through
oslo.cache and if ``keystone.conf [token] caching = True``. However,
the actual implementation doesn't check if ``keystone.conf [token]
caching = True`` at all. Even if token caching is disabled, tokens
will be cached when they are issued.

Change-Id: I1e1117deabadaba26ea8e833a06180529e1e0a4b

commit_message:
Add environment enabling memcached for cache and authtoken

If user wants they should be able to enable memcached even if it
can bring stability issues with HA.

commit_message:
[CEPH] Use civetweb by default for RGW with keystone

Currently there is a bug in the beast code that makes it fail
during the initial lookup for a keystone user map. For the time
being we will continue to use civetweb when keystone is present
until this issue is resolved.

Change-Id: I56bcd77f38adb3763d35f46443c1403816d1dcea

commit_message:
Extend method with context for segment ranges

This patch extends the ML2 type driver abstract method
``validate_provider_segment`` with ``context`` to support getting
network segment ranges from DB when network-segment-range extension is
loaded.

Co-authored-by: Allain Legacy <Allain.legacy@windriver.com>

Needed-by: https://review.openstack.org/624709
Partially-implements: blueprint network-segment-range-management
Change-Id: I212d1e5b2bf3d744488199f6aafcbdb4d0129099

subject: Switch auth order for s3 authentication
messages: [{'account_id': 935, 'date': '2019-02-21 13:19:24.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 13686, 'date': '2019-02-21 13:51:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1\n\nLGTM, thanks!'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-02-21 13:19:24.000000000', 'message': 'Switch auth order for s3 authentication

When deploying the RGW in multi-site configurations, communication
between sites is authenticated using S3 credentials managed within
RGW.  In the event that keystone authentication is in use this
generates a large number of s3 authentication attempts to keystone
which will always fail.

Switch the default order to check local auth first and then fallback
to external.

Change-Id: I7bfc016baf99188ba5a36f663145eeff465d25e8
'}]
commit_message:
Switch auth order for s3 authentication

When deploying the RGW in multi-site configurations, communication
between sites is authenticated using S3 credentials managed within
RGW.  In the event that keystone authentication is in use this
generates a large number of s3 authentication attempts to keystone
which will always fail.

Switch the default order to check local auth first and then fallback
to external.

Change-Id: I7bfc016baf99188ba5a36f663145eeff465d25e8

subject: first commit
messages:
[{'account_id': 29970, 'date': '2019-02-21 12:49:49.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 10068, 'date': '2019-02-21 12:50:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
and resubmit a new change-set.

Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. Also it
takes generally at least a couple of weeks for cores to get around to
reviewing code. The more you participate in the community the more
rewarding it is for you. You may also notice that the more you get to know
people and get to be known, the faster your patches will be reviewed and
eventually approved. Get to know others and become known by doing code
reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a great way to learn the code base.

Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

IRC: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/IRC
Workflow: https://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/developers.html
Commit Messages: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GitCommitMessages"}, {'account_id': 16222, 'date': '2019-02-21 14:00:17.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned'}]

commit_message:
[WIP] Ingress: Add security context for pod/container

This adds the security context to the ingress and ingress-error
pods. This changes the default user from root to the nobody
user.

This also adds the container security context to explicitly set
allowPrivilegeEscalation to false

commit_message:
Remove placement from nova install docs

In a fairly hack and slash fashion, remove the installation of placement
from the nova install docs. Placement will have its own installation
docs.

Configuring access to placement from the controller and compute nodes is
still described.

The depends-on is to the patch that provides placement install docs.

The output of 'nova-status upgrade check' is updated to reflect the
current state of the output of that command; this means it now
includes a fair bit more than checking cells v2 and the existence
of the placement API.

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/628220/
Change-Id: I9e082a9c6d4b6369f1ec6c17bbd3ccc417a5e97b

subject: Update nova docs front page for placement removal

[{'created': '2019-01-03 13:56:48.000000000', 'message': 'WIP: Update nova docs front page for placement removal

Remove links to internal placement documentation. Instead indicate
that placement is required by nova, and point elsewhere.

This is a WIP because the elsewhere install docs do not exist. This
commit will be updated to depends-on that when it does.

Change-Id: I9f0d52e7b46b270363946211cf6dc0c338981cb2

commit_message:
Update nova docs front page for placement removal

Remove links to internal placement documentation. Instead indicate
that placement is required by nova, and point elsewhere.

The depends-on adds placement install docs to the placement repo.

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/628220
Change-Id: I9f0d52e7b46b270363946211cf6dc0c338981cb2

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-01-03 16:46:19.000000000', 'message': "WIP: Placement install documentation

This is a first pass at creating the install documentation for
placement, by copying the nova install documentation, and removing the
nova parts, leaving the placement parts in place.

This is as yet untested, but I propose it now to get some initial
feedback on the structure and content. It's hard to know what's right
for these things these days: there used to be required patterns to
follow but now, *shrug*.

The from-pypi and verify pages are currently left as TODO.

Change-Id: I2f7bcd8efabc628bd27e3a9ce74e277a9e37fb69
"}, {'created': '2019-01-18 11:07:01.000000000', 'message': 'Placement install documentation

This is a first pass at creating the install documentation for
placement, by copying the nova install documentation, and removing the
nova parts, leaving the placement parts in place.

The expectation here is that this provides a starting point which
can be iteratively improved, perfection being the enemy of the
done and all that.

The from-pypi and verify pages are currently left as TODO and not
included in the visible table of contents. They are present in
the hidden table of contents.

Change-Id: I2f7bcd8efabc628bd27e3a9ce74e277a9e37fb69
'}]
commit_message:
Placement install documentation

This is a first pass at creating the install documentation for
placement, by copying the nova install documentation, and removing the
nova parts, leaving the placement parts in place.

The expectation here is that this provides a starting point which
can be iteratively improved, perfection being the enemy of the
done and all that.

The from-pypi and verify pages are currently left as TODO and not
included in the visible table of contents. They are present in
the hidden table of contents.

Change-Id: I2f7bcd8efabc628bd27e3a9ce74e277a9e37fb69

commit_message:
use rpc from neutron-lib

We recently removed nenutron.common.rpc [1] as the rpc module lives in
neutron-lib now. This project was missed because I didn't find
neutron.common.rpc as an import.

This patch switches rpc uses over to neutron-lib.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/634790/

Change-Id: I8cba8fd54493661f100be155cf46fce7fff37277

[{'created': '2019-02-14 13:28:29.000000000', 'message': 'fix lower constraints

Lower constraints jobs are failing when using depends-on with a
neutron patch due to ryu lower constraint not matching what neutron
needs for ryu [1].

This patch removes ryu from the lower-constraints as ryu is not required
directly by this project.

[1] http://logs.openstack.org/79/635179/1/check/openstack-tox-lower-constraints/
a03aedd/job-output.txt.gz#_2019-02-08_18_20_19_587482

Change-Id: Ib319c5ba5651b81122e16856dcfff247498a2ca3
'}]
commit_message:
fix lower constraints

Lower constraints jobs are failing when using depends-on with a
neutron patch due to ryu lower constraint not matching what neutron
needs for ryu [1].

This patch removes ryu from the lower-constraints as ryu is not required
directly by this project.

[1] http://logs.openstack.org/79/635179/1/check/openstack-tox-lower-constraints/
a03aedd/job-output.txt.gz#_2019-02-08_18_20_19_587482

Change-Id: Ib319c5ba5651b81122e16856dcfff247498a2ca3

commit_message:
use payloads for PORT BEFORE_DELETE callbacks

This patch switches BEFORE_DELETE callback events for PORT resources
over to the payload style args use a DBEventPayload object.
It also switches over to neutron-lib's exceptions which otherwise
will cause failures.

Change-Id: I00241892ca067adc28b7af39aef8573488e44bb0

Add octavia l7policies scenarios

Add the following scenarios for Octavia:

- Octavia.create_and_list_l7policy
- Octavia.create_and_delete_l7policy
- Octavia.create_and_update_l7policy
- Octavia.create_and_show_l7policy

commit_message:
FFWD: Introduce workaround for neutron cisco plugin

Neutron cisco plugin package update is not triggered by update of
neutron package. If this plugin is enabled the neutron db sync
will fail unless we update python-networking-cisco package.

Change-Id: I3ac3d9baf51c7a9e13d20985fbe47cd5404eb88d
Resolves: rhbz#1652209
Closes-bug: #1804494
(backport from commit 4e8c2faf36d94257760b5d07195e1d90fefbc2c4)

commit_message:
simplify the links to operating systems

Combine the links in the list and remove the redundant use of "latest"
on each line.

Change-Id: I44c19d0c6c39e6624c76bfdf8a3e433b5e22983b
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2019-01-28 09:32:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Published edit on patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 8482, 'date': '2019-01-28 09:34:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 2394, 'date': '2019-01-28 10:58:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2019-01-28 13:06:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Rollcall-Vote+1

Great to see this added!'}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2019-01-28 13:54:21.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

If this is the form that the document is going to keep, then yes, it is only appropriate that openSUSE be listed

However I continue to dispute that we should be listing multiple distros in the testing reference and recommending testing multiple distros in the testing reference. We should test one, very modern, distro upstream, and distros should test themselves downstream.

However, I recognize I'm in the minority on this sort of thing, so I don't want to belabor the point.

This change is an improvement."}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2019-01-28 14:32:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

> If this is the form that the document is going to keep, then yes,
 > it is only appropriate that openSUSE be listed
 > 
 > However I continue to dispute that we should be listing multiple
 > distros in the testing reference and recommending testing multiple
 > distros in the testing reference. We should test one, very modern,
 > distro upstream, and distros should test themselves downstream.
 > 
 > However, I recognize I'm in the minority on this sort of thing, so
 > I don't want to belabor the point.
 > 
 > This change is an improvement.

I think your proposition is a very valid one, and it would be nice to challenge the status quo there. However, I don't think "your" approach ([1]) should be at the expense of this inclusive approach.

[1]: sorry to use that phrasing it's just easier to read'}, {'account_id': 4162, 'date': '2019-01-28 23:12:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-01-28 09:23:51.000000000', 'message': 'Amend reference/PTI to add openSUSE

When the Ubuntu and CentOS were added in the PTI as "supported
distros", SUSE was already one of the most-popular distros [1],
and therefore deserves listing here.

I don't believe the PTI should refer to "popular" term for distros,
as this isn't a popularity contest. Instead, we should allow any
distribution where community effort is provided.

In this case, openSUSE images are present in infra, and SUSE contributors
are using devstack on openSUSE. Next to that, "deployment" projects like
OpenStack-Ansible or openstack-helm are making use of openSUSE.

Last, but not least, some projects already take into account openSUSE
in their regular work. For example, when the nova team contacts the
distributions at the beginning of the cycle to know their latest
supported libvirt [2].

I believe all these arguments are enough to warrant the addition of
openSUSE in the list of distributions.

[1]: SUSE was ranked 4th in that survey (with SLES), after RHEL (3rd).
[2]: http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2018-September/135007.html

Change-Id: I1ac3b7477b5d4cb4af75c319b4232d20b4b4b284

commit_message:
Amend reference/PTI to add openSUSE

When the Ubuntu and CentOS were added in the PTI as "supported
distros", SUSE was already one of the most-popular distros [1],
and therefore deserves listing here.

I don't believe the PTI should refer to "popular" term for distros,
as this isn't a popularity contest. Instead, we should allow any
distribution where community effort is provided.

In this case, openSUSE images are present in infra, and SUSE contributors
are using devstack on openSUSE. Next to that, deployment projects like
openstack-ansible or openstack-helm are making use of openSUSE.

Last, but not least, some projects already take into account openSUSE
in their regular work (for example, when the nova team contacts the
distributions at the beginning of the cycle to know their latest
supported libvirt [2]).

I believe all these arguments are enough to warrant the addition of
openSUSE in the list of distributions.

[1]: SUSE was ranked 4th in that survey (with SLES), after RHEL (3rd).
[2]: http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2018-September/135007.html

Change-Id: I1ac3b7477b5d4cb4af75c319b4232d20b4b4b284

commit_message:
Set up DB schema in DevStack plugin using Alembic

SQL schema scripts are replaced with Alembic command line tool.
Notification plugins are enabled in notification engine configuration
file.

The change also fixes the `sub_alarm` table schema. The foreign key must
refer to the field with the same data type, charset and collation.
Otherwise the schema migration fails occasionally with Python 3 with the
IntegrityError[1]:

  oslo_db.exception.DBError: (pymysql.err.IntegrityError) (1215, 'Cannot add foreign key constraint')

[1] http://logs.openstack.org/61/622361/8/gate/monasca-tempest-python3-influxdb/26104a3/controller/logs/devstacklog.txt.gz#_2019-01-30_15_52_45_455

Change-Id: I95d7e91e62ff13e84f963fdbb3bca6b7dfd7c310
Story: 2001654
Task: 14421

commit_message:
Deploy templates: data model, DB API & objects

Adds deploy_templates and deploy_template_steps tables to the database,
provides a DB API for these tables, and a DeployTemplate versioned
object.

Change-Id: I5b8b59bbea1594b1220438050b80f1c603dbc346
Story: 1722275
Task: 28674

subject: Fix per-project deprecation badges
messages:
[{'account_id': 2394, 'date': '2019-02-21 11:08:03.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 2394, 'date': '2019-02-21 11:11:25.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I'm 90% sure this will work, but I don't see any easy way to test it without changing openstackdocstheme to point to a local openstack-manuals instead of to https://docs.openstack.org/$RELEASE/badge.html."}, {'account_id': 2394, 'date': '2019-02-21 11:27:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

You can now see examples of the per-project badges in the Zuul job and compare them to what is already online, e.g.

http://logs.openstack.org/96/638396/1/check/build-tox-manuals-checkbuild/1376322/publish-docs/www/queens/badge.html
https://docs.openstack.org/queens/badge.html
http://logs.openstack.org/96/638396/1/check/build-tox-manuals-checkbuild/1376322/publish-docs/www/rocky/badge.html
https://docs.openstack.org/rocky/badge.html

Note that the "latest" badge is unchanged:

http://logs.openstack.org/96/638396/1/check/build-tox-manuals-checkbuild/1376322/publish-docs/www/latest/badge.html
https://docs.openstack.org/latest/badge.html

and you can also see that the release switcher dropdown is still present for pages generated within openstack-manuals, e.g.

http://logs.openstack.org/96/638396/1/check/build-tox-manuals-checkbuild/1376322/publish-docs/www/rocky/language-bindings.html'}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2019-02-21 12:07:35.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2

I can't say yay or nay so let's just do it and see"}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2019-02-21 12:08:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Workflow+1

and, in fact, I'm going to fast approve just to get it in the wild asap"}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-02-21 11:08:03.000000000', 'message': 'Fix per-project deprecation badges

I2498f00a6c863d078a70289a655b0aa3958325ed changed the badge shown at
the top of documentation pages which describes the state of the
release of the documentation currently being viewed.  However the
unfortunately release-switcher dropdown it introduced into
deprecated_badge.tmpl had the side-effect of affecting the badge.html
which is dynamically included in project documentation by some
Javascript in theme/openstackdocs/layout.html within the
openstackdocstheme repository, and the new release switcher was only
designed to work with openstack-manuals, not with any other projects.

This broke the badge for all releases (www/$RELEASE/badge.html),
excluding www/latest/ which has a hard-coded badge.html.  This was
missed during testing because the dynamic inclusion mechanism is
hardcoded to retrieve the badge from https://docs.openstack.org rather
than any local repository.

For a quick fix, reintroduce the old badge template as

    www/templates/project_deprecated_badge.tmpl

and change all the per-project badges to use this.  Later we can
investigate the possibility of enhancing this per-project badge so
that it provides release-switching functionality like the badge
currently in openstack-manuals.

Change-Id: I53c4b35e31bcdda16ffd50f9a8a26c773c8d3574
'}]
commit_message:
Fix per-project deprecation badges

I2498f00a6c863d078a70289a655b0aa3958325ed changed the badge shown at
the top of documentation pages which describes the state of the
release of the documentation currently being viewed.  However the
unfortunately release-switcher dropdown it introduced into
deprecated_badge.tmpl had the side-effect of affecting the badge.html
which is dynamically included in project documentation by some
Javascript in theme/openstackdocs/layout.html within the
openstackdocstheme repository, and the new release switcher was only
designed to work with openstack-manuals, not with any other projects.

This broke the badge for all releases (www/$RELEASE/badge.html),
excluding www/latest/ which has a hard-coded badge.html.  This was
missed during testing because the dynamic inclusion mechanism is
hardcoded to retrieve the badge from https://docs.openstack.org rather
than any local repository.

For a quick fix, reintroduce the old badge template as

    www/templates/project_deprecated_badge.tmpl

and change all the per-project badges to use this.  Later we can
investigate the possibility of enhancing this per-project badge so
that it provides release-switching functionality like the badge
currently in openstack-manuals.

Change-Id: I53c4b35e31bcdda16ffd50f9a8a26c773c8d3574

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-12-17 16:25:48.000000000', 'message': 'Reigstering RouterInfo by L3 extention API

Currently, most plugin implementations releated L3 override the L3NatAgent
class itself for their own logic since there is no proper interface to extend
RouterInfo class. This adds unnecessary complexity for developers who just
want to extend agent mechanism instead of whole RPC related to L3
functinalities.

This spec introduces RouterFactory class which acts on the factory for creating
RouterInfo class, and add new l3 extension API which enable to dynamically
add RouterInfo to the factory. Now plugin developers can use new extension
API for their own specific router.

Change-Id: Ic3486830e449f6ee8dbe19db614179b2077bcf7b
Implements: blueprint router-factory-with-l3-extension

This spec introduces RouterFactory class which acts on the factory for
creating RouterInfo class, and add new l3 extension API which enable to
dynamically add RouterInfo to the factory. Now plugin developers can

commit_message:
Registering RouterInfo by L3 extention API

Currently, most plugin implementations releated L3 override the
L3NatAgent class itself for their own logic since there is no proper
interface to extend RouterInfo class. This adds unnecessary complexity
for developers who just want to extend agent mechanism instead of
whole RPC related to L3 functinalities.

This spec introduces RouterFactory class which acts on the factory for
creating RouterInfo class, and add new l3 extension API which enable to
dynamically add RouterInfo to the factory. Now plugin developers can
use new extension API for their own specific router.

Change-Id: Ic3486830e449f6ee8dbe19db614179b2077bcf7b
Related-Bug: #1804634
Implements: blueprint router-factory-with-l3-extension

commit_message:
Remove the container cli override for standalone scenario 1-3

With [1] we remove pacemaker from scenario standalone and with [2]
we already switch to using podman for container cli.

This removes the now redundant override from the job definitions.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/636563/
[2] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/637859/

Change-Id: I543c5984ed9fa604305629f82cc070853888bcf0

commit_message:
base/centos: stop treating AArch64 in special way

All repositories we depend on got synced to mirrors. So we no longer
need to fetch ceph-luminous or opstools from buildlogs.centos.org
server.

Change-Id: Ie7b54d20f98d26d3e086bbbfcda289c2677a008a
(cherry-pick from c7b2bbf550a9a02fda09e26362150129f3bb9588)

Change TripleO job to run against scenario 3

After the switch in TripleO to ML2/OVN [0], scenario007 was flipped
to ML2/OVS so we'll gate against scenario 3 from now on.

CentOS team synced virt/kvm-common repository for alternate archs. We
can just install 'centos-release-qemu-ev' package like it is done on
x86-64.

Change-Id: Ie45a0b83fc4460d5dfce82efca061272db974ead
(cherry-pick from eb321e4827c9cb73861168ba8dcc488a7e9a9eb1)

commit_message:
centos: clean altarch repositories situation a bit

CentOS team synced virt/kvm-common repository for alternate archs. We
can just install 'centos-release-qemu-ev' package like it is done on
x86-64.

Change-Id: Ie45a0b83fc4460d5dfce82efca061272db974ead
(cherry-pick from eb321e4827c9cb73861168ba8dcc488a7e9a9eb1)

commit_message:
nova: Only install OVMF packages on RHEL 7

These packages have been provided as direct dependencies of QEMU in more
recent versions of Fedora and will continue to be for RHEL 8 and it's
derived distributions.

https://src.fedoraproject.org/rpms/qemu/blob/f29/f/qemu.spec#_820

Change-Id: Ic8f865ed9cfc89056991ce4fa50a99c4937af33b

commit_message:
debian/ubuntu: introduce 'debian_arch' variable

Many images have 'if x86_64 then amd64 elif aarch64 then arm64' check to
comply with Debian like architecture names in several projects.

This patch creates 'debian_arch' variable which can be used in all
Docker files (similar to 'base_arch' one).

All required images got converted to use it.

Change-Id: I9c5e6f13d6c9b24fe323408512bd5aef290111ad

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-10-15 16:30:55.000000000', 'message': "Change python3.5 job to python3.7 job on Stein+

This is a mechanically generated patch to add a unit test job running
under Python 3.7 and drop the Python 3.5 unit test job.

python3.5 was the only supported python3 version on Xenial. Now that
we have Bionic nodes supporting python3.6 and python3.7, let's switch
to testing with python3.7 in addition to python3.6 in Stein and
beyond.

See ML discussion here [1] for context.

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2018-October/135626.html

Change-Id: I9a72540b03b41378600c85691b99b5e0e497f846
Story: #2004073
Task: #27440
"}, {'created': '2019-02-14 10:22:10.000000000', 'message': "Change python3.5 job to python3.7 job on Stein+

under Python 3.7 and drop the Python 3.5 unit test job.

python3.5 was the only supported python3 version on Xenial. Now that
we have Bionic nodes supporting python3.6 and python3.7, let's switch
to testing with python3.7 in addition to python3.6 in Stein and
beyond.

See ML discussion here [1] for context.

commit_message:
Change python3.5 job to python3.7 job on Stein+

This is a mechanically generated patch to add a unit test job running
under Python 3.7 and drop the Python 3.5 unit test job.

python3.5 was the only supported python3 version on Xenial. Now that
we have Bionic nodes supporting python3.6 and python3.7, let's switch
to testing with python3.7 in addition to python3.6 in Stein and
beyond.

See ML discussion here [1] for context.

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2018-October/135626.html

Change-Id: I9a72540b03b41378600c85691b99b5e0e497f846
Story: #2004073
Task: #27440

commit_message:
pypi package msgpack-python is deprecated, drop explicit install

according to https://pypi.org/project/msgpack-python/ it's
deprecated and should use msgpack.

and this is supported by looking at a build source container
image and noting that pip lists

msgpack                 0.6.0
msgpack-python          0.5.6

also msgpack is pulled in via dependency of oslo.serialization

We should be able to rely on it coming in via that dependency
automaticly

Change-Id: Id2706b3b38e57daf1166f98a59dc3ecd30fd4fa7

commit_message:
Change python3.5 job to python3.7 job on Stein+

python3.5 was the only supported python3 version on Xenial, now that we have
Bionic Beaver nodes that support python3.7, lets switch to testing with
python3.7 in addition with python3.6 in Stein and beyond.
See ML discussion here [1] for context.

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2018-October/135632.html

It's somewhat late in the cycle but 3.0.0 has been out for some time now (January 2017) and this does allow for a significant clean up and we've given good warning about the upcoming version bump"}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-02-13 14:16:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

(1 comment)

I've asked Kashyap to send another reminder to the mailing list and copy the zKVM CI maintainers from [1] to make sure they are OK with this since I don't see zKVM CI running anymore. Otherwise I think if we don't hear any objections by the end of the week then we can go ahead. The last time we did a minimum libvirt/qemu version bump was in Pike which gives us about a year of buffer for people to prepare for the "next" minimum version which is this change.

[1] https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/ThirdPartySystems/IBM_zKVM_CI'}, {'account_id': 6962, 'date': '2019-02-13 14:21:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 6962, 'date': '2019-02-13 14:45:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

> (1 comment)
 > 
 > I've asked Kashyap to send another reminder to the mailing list and
 > copy the zKVM CI maintainers from [1] to make sure they are OK with
 > this since I don't see zKVM CI running anymore. 

As promised on IRC, here we go:

http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-February/002665.html ("[ops][nova] Heads-up: Upcoming version bump for libvirt and QEMU in 'Stein'")

 > Otherwise I think
 > if we don't hear any objections by the end of the week then we can
 > go ahead. The last time we did a minimum libvirt/qemu version bump
 > was in Pike which gives us about a year of buffer for people to
 > prepare for the "next" minimum version which is this change.
 > 
 > [1] https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/ThirdPartySystems/IBM_zKVM_CI'}, {'account_id': 23498, 'date': '2019-02-13 14:59:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

- check-nova-master http://extbasicopstackcilog01.podc.sl.edst.ibm.com/test_logs/jenkins-check-nova-master-27577 : FAILURE in 59m 41s'}, {'account_id': 28454, 'date': '2019-02-13 16:50:04.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8:

(3 comments)

Added some Nits and comments.

Overall, I can not yet fully estimate the impact of this change.
As of now I think it won't hurt, but to really understand the current and the new behaviour I'd have to create some real-life instances.
(And I'm not sure when I will have time for that)."}, {'account_id': 26515, 'date': '2019-02-13 18:51:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

Some generic observations on the console/serial functionality
(just to understand the problem properly)

Please correct me if some observations, assumptions or deductions are wrong:
- virtlogd may (or may not) be installed
  (detected with _is_virtlogd_available() in old code)
- virtlogd may be active or not (configued in qemu, not detected by driver)
- if virtlogd is active, it provides some extra functionality like
  logfile rotation
- I do not know exactly how virtlogd integrates in qemu/kvm AFAIK it
  doesn't matter and only affects the way how the data gets in the file.

- TCP-based (interactive) consoles use the <log file='/bla/'> mechanism to
  provide a logfile.
- PTY-based (regular) consoles have both the <source path='/dev/pts/0'> and
  the <log file='/bla/'> structure. The driver transfers the data from the pty
  to the logfile whenever the log is read.
  I would assume that the data gets duplicated this way but obviously things
  work well. Does the <log file=''> directive consume the data? Maybe someone
  can enlighten me there.
- I didn't find a way to generate a file based console and couldn't test this case.
  If file-based consoles are now obsolete some parts of the code just cover
  legacy configurations/cases and should be marked as such.

Are there any exceptions when using non-qemu/kvm hypervisors?

I would really appreciate if we could cut the table down to the options
'pty' and 'tcp' and simplify the overly complex control flow (either here
or on a followup change)."}, {'account_id': 28454, 'date': '2019-02-15 15:39:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10:

(4 comments)

Some suggestions to improve control flow.'}, {'account_id': 6962, 'date': '2019-02-18 10:18:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 6962, 'date': '2019-02-18 11:21:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10:

(1 comment)

Thanks, George, for the detailed review.  I'll address them.  Some 
responses to your review.

- The way 'virtlogd' integrates with QEMU is described in the original 
  'virtlogd' libvirt patch series.  Let me quote the relevant bit:

    "Currently we have stdout + stderr of QEMU guests setup to write
    to a log file (eg /var/log/libvirt/qemu/$GUEST.log). This is nice
    and simple, but it in fact opens the possibility of a malicious or
    accidental denial of service, whereby QEMU can write logs of data
    to stdio and thus fill up the host filesystem holding the log.

    ...

    "The only way to solve this is to not let QEMU directly write to
    the log file, instead connect its stdio to a pipe and copy data
    from the pipe to the real log file, performing file rollover
    when it reaches a certain size.
   
    "If we do this, we need something to keep open the pipe for as long
    as QEMU is running. This can't be libvirtd since we expect libvirtd
    to be able to be stopped while QEMU is running. Thus we introduce a
    new single-purpose daemon virtlogd whose job is exclusively to deal
    with log file writing. This daemon has support for SIGUSR1 to tell
    it to re-exec itself while keeping open the pipe to QEMU so it can
    be safely upgraded while QEMU is running."

- Do we even _need_ two serial console devices in this case -- "sclplm" 
  (a separate log) and "sclp" (interactive)?  Talking to libvirt
  upstream folks: they suggested to remove the duplication altogether.
  
- Yes, I agree with you on further simplification of the control flow —
  but it should be done in a separate change.

And related reading:
https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/nova-specs/specs/ocata/implemented/libvirt-virtlogd.html
https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/nova-specs/specs/kilo/implemented/libvirt-kvm-systemz.html'}, {'account_id': 6962, 'date': '2019-02-18 12:09:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10:

On Friday, uncovered the following issue with zKVM bug:

With `virtlogd` available, having *both* s390x consoles, "sclplm" and 
"sclp" does not make sense — as 'virtlogd' will try to open duplicate 
consoles:

    2019-02-15 08:39:52.292+0000: 3015: error :
     virNetClientProgramDispatchError:177 : Cannot open log file:
     '/opt/stack/data/nova/instances/6cabfc83-8056-4282-9918-f4e349bb6169/console.log':
     Device or resource busy

As can be observed from the log s390x Nova Compute log:
---
Feb 15 08:39:43.093482 ubuntu-xenial-s390x-cloud-zfwcec175-6757 nova-compute[18734]:     <console type='pty'>
Feb 15 08:39:43.093639 ubuntu-xenial-s390x-cloud-zfwcec175-6757 nova-compute[18734]:       <log file='/opt/stack/data/nova/instances/35329c2e-d278-4629-87ad-08795d0a68c8/console.log' append='off'/>
Feb 15 08:39:43.093782 ubuntu-xenial-s390x-cloud-zfwcec175-6757 nova-compute[18734]:       <target type='sclplm' port='0'/>
Feb 15 08:39:43.093922 ubuntu-xenial-s390x-cloud-zfwcec175-6757 nova-compute[18734]:     </console>
Feb 15 08:39:43.094057 ubuntu-xenial-s390x-cloud-zfwcec175-6757 nova-compute[18734]:     <console type='pty'>
Feb 15 08:39:43.094190 ubuntu-xenial-s390x-cloud-zfwcec175-6757 nova-compute[18734]:       <log file='/opt/stack/data/nova/instances/35329c2e-d278-4629-87ad-08795d0a68c8/console.log' append='off'/>
Feb 15 08:39:43.094328 ubuntu-xenial-s390x-cloud-zfwcec175-6757 nova-compute[18734]:       <target type='sclp' port='1'/>
Feb 15 08:39:43.094470 ubuntu-xenial-s390x-cloud-zfwcec175-6757 nova-compute[18734]:     </console>
---'}, {'account_id': 6962, 'date': '2019-02-18 12:59:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10:

[{'created': '2019-01-22 16:33:57.000000000', 'message': '[WIP] libvirt: Bump MIN_{LIBVIRT,QEMU}_VERSION for "Stein"

In commit: b980df0[1], we advertized the NEXT_MIN_LIBVIRT and
NEXT_MIN_QEMU_VERSION for Stein to be:

    libvirt 1.3.1 and QEMU 2.5.0

Now that we're in the development cycle for "Stein", bump it to the
above agreed-upon versions.

[1] http://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/nova/commit/?id=28d337b --
    Pick next minimum libvirt / QEMU versions for "Stein"

Change-Id: I408baef12358a83921c4693b847a692f6c19e36f
Signed-off-by: Kashyap Chamarthy <kchamart@redhat.com>
'}, {'created': '2019-01-22 17:18:41.000000000', 'message': '[WIP] libvirt: Bump MIN_{LIBVIRT,QEMU}_VERSION for "Stein"

In commit: b980df0[1], we advertized the NEXT_MIN_LIBVIRT and
NEXT_MIN_QEMU_VERSION for Stein to be:

    libvirt 1.3.1 and QEMU 2.5.0

Now that we are in the development cycle for "Stein", bump the
MIN_{LIBVIRT,QEMU}_VERSION to the above agreed-upon versions.

And the following now needless version constants (and corresponding
tests) will be removed in separate patches:

        MIN_LIBVIRT_PARALLELS_SET_ADMIN_PASSWD
        MIN_LIBVIRT_VIRTLOGD MIN_QEMU_VIRTLOGD
        MIN_LIBVIRT_POSTCOPY_VERSION
        MIN_LIBVIRT_PERF_VERSION
        MIN_LIBVIRT_LUKS_VERSION and MIN_QEMU_LUKS_VERSION
        MIN_QEMU_FILE_BACKED_VERSION

[1] http://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/nova/commit/?id=28d337b --
    Pick next minimum libvirt / QEMU versions for "Stein"

Change-Id: I408baef12358a83921c4693b847a692f6c19e36f
Signed-off-by: Kashyap Chamarthy <kchamart@redhat.com>
'}, {'created': '2019-01-23 15:09:44.000000000', 'message': '[WIP] libvirt: Bump MIN_{LIBVIRT,QEMU}_VERSION for "Stein"

In commit 28d337b[1], we advertized that the NEXT_MIN_LIBVIRT and
NEXT_MIN_QEMU_VERSION for "Stein" will be:

    libvirt 3.0.0 and QEMU 2.5.0

Now that we are in the development cycle for "Stein", bump the
MIN_{LIBVIRT,QEMU}_VERSION to the above agreed-upon versions.

As part of the clean-up is also removing the "allow access to a Nova
instance via `virsh console <guest>` in _create_pty_device(), because it
is not required.  I also double-checked with Daniel Berrangé, who said
(slightly paraphrasing):

    Nova should not allow `virsh console` to guests behind its back at
    all.  And especially it should not care about `virsh console`
    working with "tcp".  The point of using "tcp" consoles in Nova is
    that it provides tunneling via the Nova "serial console server".
    You can only have 1 thing connected to a console at a time — so if
    the Nova serial console is present, `virsh console` can't be used
    anyway.

(I wanted to avoid making the above change as part of this cleanup,
because "the cardinal rule for creating good commits is to ensure there
is only one 'logical change' per commit".  But as far as I know, it
seems unavoidable.)

The rest of the version constants (and corresponding tests) that are now
no longer required will be removed in separate patches:

    MIN_LIBVIRT_PARALLELS_SET_ADMIN_PASSWD,
    MIN_LIBVIRT_POSTCOPY_VERSION, MIN_{LIBVIRT,QEMU}_LUKS_VERSION,
    MIN_QEMU_FILE_BACKED_VERSION

[1] http://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/nova/commit/?id=28d337b --
    Pick next minimum libvirt / QEMU versions for "Stein"

Change-Id: I408baef12358a83921c4693b847a692f6c19e36f
Signed-off-by: Kashyap Chamarthy <kchamart@redhat.com>
'}, {'created': '2019-02-12 15:04:07.000000000', 'message': '[WIP] libvirt: Bump MIN_{LIBVIRT,QEMU}_VERSION for "Stein"

As part of the clean-up, this change is also removing the "allow access
to a Nova instance via `virsh console <guest>`" in _create_pty_device(),
because it is not required.  I also double-checked with Daniel Berrangé,
who said (slightly paraphrasing):

    Nova should not allow `virsh console` to guests behind its back at
    all.  And especially it should not care about `virsh console`
    working with "tcp".  The point of using "tcp" consoles in Nova is
    that it provides tunneling via the Nova "serial console server".
    You can only have 1 thing connected to a console at a time — so if
    the Nova serial console is present, `virsh console` can't be used
    anyway.

(I wanted to avoid making the above change as part of this cleanup,
because "the cardinal rule for creating good commits is to ensure there
is only one 'logical change' per commit".  But as far as I know, it
seems unavoidable.)

The rest of the version constants (and corresponding tests) that are now
no longer required will be removed in separate patches:

    MIN_LIBVIRT_PARALLELS_SET_ADMIN_PASSWD,
    MIN_LIBVIRT_POSTCOPY_VERSION, MIN_{LIBVIRT,QEMU}_LUKS_VERSION,
    MIN_QEMU_FILE_BACKED_VERSION

    Pick next minimum libvirt / QEMU versions for "Stein"

Change-Id: I408baef12358a83921c4693b847a692f6c19e36f
Signed-off-by: Kashyap Chamarthy <kchamart@redhat.com>
'}, {'created': '2019-02-12 19:13:51.000000000', 'message': 'libvirt: Bump MIN_{LIBVIRT,QEMU}_VERSION for "Stein"

In commit 28d337b[1], we advertized that the NEXT_MIN_LIBVIRT and
NEXT_MIN_QEMU_VERSION for "Stein" will be:

    libvirt 3.0.0 and QEMU 2.5.0

Now that we are in the development cycle for "Stein", bump the
MIN_{LIBVIRT,QEMU}_VERSION to the above agreed-upon versions.

As part of this clean-up:

  - Remove the requirement for extra serial device (added in commit:
    1f65925: "libvirt: virtlogd: use virtlogd for char devices"), that
    "allows access to a Nova instance via `virsh console <guest>`" in
    _create_pty_device() — it is not required.  I also double-checked
    with libvirt and QEMU developer Daniel Berrangé, who said (slightly
    paraphrasing):

        "Nova should not allow `virsh console` to guests behind its back
        at all.  And especially it should not care about `virsh console`
        working with "tcp".  The point of using "tcp" consoles in Nova
        is that it provides tunneling via the Nova "serial console
        server".  You can only have 1 thing connected to a console at a
        time — so if the Nova serial console is present, `virsh console`
        can't be used anyway."

    (I wanted to avoid making the above change as part of this cleanup,
    because "the cardinal rule for creating good commits is to ensure
    there is only one 'logical change' per commit".  But in this case,
    it is simply unavoidable.)

  - The unit test noise is largely mechanical: remove the superflous
    serial device, and lower the index of the devices by 1.

The following version constants (and corresponding tests), that are now
no longer required, will be removed in separate patches:

    MIN_LIBVIRT_PARALLELS_SET_ADMIN_PASSWD,
    MIN_LIBVIRT_POSTCOPY_VERSION, MIN_{LIBVIRT,QEMU}_LUKS_VERSION,
    MIN_QEMU_FILE_BACKED_VERSION

[1] http://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/nova/commit/?id=28d337b --
    Pick next minimum libvirt / QEMU versions for "Stein"

Change-Id: I408baef12358a83921c4693b847a692f6c19e36f
Signed-off-by: Kashyap Chamarthy <kchamart@redhat.com>
'}, {'created': '2019-02-12 20:27:59.000000000', 'message': 'libvirt: Bump MIN_{LIBVIRT,QEMU}_VERSION for "Stein"

In commit 28d337b[1], we advertized that the NEXT_MIN_LIBVIRT and
NEXT_MIN_QEMU_VERSION for "Stein" will be:

    libvirt 3.0.0 and QEMU 2.8.0

Now that we are in the development cycle for "Stein", bump the
MIN_{LIBVIRT,QEMU}_VERSION to the above agreed-upon versions.

As part of this clean-up:

  - Remove the _create_file_device() function and the calls to it; it is
    a "no-op" when virtlogd is available.  As a result of this, in
    _create_consoles_s390x(), this commit changes the console type 'pty'
    instead of 'file' for s390x's "sclplm" console device.  This is
    valid, as the guest does not care about what is done in the backend.

  - Remove the requirement for extra serial device (added in commit:
    1f65925: "libvirt: virtlogd: use virtlogd for char devices"), that
    "allows access to a Nova instance via `virsh console <guest>`" in
    _create_pty_device() — it is not required.  I also double-checked
    with libvirt and QEMU developer Daniel Berrangé, who said (slightly
    paraphrasing):

        "Nova should not allow `virsh console` to guests behind its back
        at all.  And especially it should not care about `virsh console`
        working with "tcp".  The point of using "tcp" consoles in Nova
        is that it provides tunneling via the Nova "serial console
        server".  You can only have 1 thing connected to a console at a
        time — so if the Nova serial console is present, `virsh console`
        can't be used anyway."

  - The unit test noise is largely mechanical: remove the superflous
    serial device, and lower the index of the devices by 1.

The following version constants (and corresponding tests), that are now
no longer required, will be removed in separate patches:

    MIN_LIBVIRT_PARALLELS_SET_ADMIN_PASSWD,
    MIN_LIBVIRT_POSTCOPY_VERSION, MIN_{LIBVIRT,QEMU}_LUKS_VERSION,
    MIN_QEMU_FILE_BACKED_VERSION

[1] http://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/nova/commit/?id=28d337b --
    Pick next minimum libvirt / QEMU versions for "Stein"

Change-Id: I408baef12358a83921c4693b847a692f6c19e36f
Signed-off-by: Kashyap Chamarthy <kchamart@redhat.com>

commit_message:
libvirt: Bump MIN_{LIBVIRT,QEMU}_VERSION for "Stein"

In commit 28d337b[1], we advertized that the NEXT_MIN_LIBVIRT and
NEXT_MIN_QEMU_VERSION for "Stein" will be:

    libvirt 3.0.0 and QEMU 2.8.0

Now that we are in the development cycle for "Stein", bump the
MIN_{LIBVIRT,QEMU}_VERSION to the above agreed-upon versions.

As part of this clean-up:

  - Remove the _create_file_device() function and the calls to it; it is
    a "no-op" when 'virtlogd' is available.  As a result of this, in
    _create_consoles_s390x(), this patch entirely removes the "sclplm"
    serial console device — otherwise 'virtlogd', which is now always
    available, will create a duplicate 'pty' devices ("sclplm" and
    "sclp") pointing to the same log, which results in instance creation
    failure; we don't want that.

  - Remove the requirement for extra serial device (added in commit:
    1f65925: "libvirt: virtlogd: use virtlogd for char devices"), that
    "allows access to a Nova instance via `virsh console <guest>`" in
    _create_pty_device() — it is not required.  I also double-checked
    with libvirt and QEMU developer Daniel Berrangé, who said (slightly
    paraphrasing):

        "Nova should not allow `virsh console` to guests behind its back
        at all.  And especially it should not care about `virsh console`
        working with "tcp".  The point of using "tcp" consoles in Nova
        is that it provides tunneling via the Nova "serial console
        server".  You can only have 1 thing connected to a console at a
        time — so if the Nova serial console is present, `virsh console`
        can't be used anyway."

  - The unit test noise is largely mechanical: remove the superflous
    serial device, and lower the index of the devices by 1.

The following version constants (and corresponding tests), that are now
no longer required, will be removed in separate patches:

    MIN_LIBVIRT_PARALLELS_SET_ADMIN_PASSWD,
    MIN_LIBVIRT_POSTCOPY_VERSION, MIN_{LIBVIRT,QEMU}_LUKS_VERSION,
    MIN_QEMU_FILE_BACKED_VERSION, MIN_LIBVIRT_PERF_VERSION

[1] http://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/nova/commit/?id=28d337b --
    Pick next minimum libvirt / QEMU versions for "Stein"

Change-Id: I408baef12358a83921c4693b847a692f6c19e36f
Signed-off-by: Kashyap Chamarthy <kchamart@redhat.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2017-01-20 22:27:15.000000000', 'message': 'Remove yaml string deprecation warning

Starting from Ocata tacker payloads will only accept
YAML dict for config and param payload values. Hence
remove the warning when something other than YAML dict
is received by the API.

Change-Id: I9f06bf0e0f89b6633c25994b7a7d08cdf93547a2

commit_message:
Remove yaml string deprecation warning

Starting from Ocata tacker payloads will only accept
YAML dict for config and param payload values. Hence
remove the warning when something other than YAML dict
is received by the API.

Change-Id: I9f06bf0e0f89b6633c25994b7a7d08cdf93547a2
Closes-Bug: #1656416
Co-Authored-By: lijiale<lijiale@cmss.chinamobile.com>
Co-Authored-By: Dharmendra Kushwaha<dharmendra.kushwaha@india.nec.com>

are 'greyed' out and you are unable to click.

in Chrome and Firefox.

commit_message:
Fixing the "where to next?" buttons

The buttons underneath "What Are The Next Steps?" work for a
brief moment (clickable and workable) but then they
are 'greyed' out and you are unable to click. This is because
the use of float was taking the buttons out of the normal
flow of the page.

This fix places the buttons inside a div with the
"clearfix" class[1].

[1] https://getbootstrap.com/docs/4.0/utilities/clearfix/

Change-Id: I31d9d8a1e064a7a930de45682b3eaf1a35ece525
Closes-bug: 1811964

commit_message:
standalone/undercloud do not cover full mistral workflow

The standalone job is started via a heat process
that skips a portion of the mistral workflow that
is used in overcloud deployments.

An example of missed coverage:
https://bugs.launchpad.net/tripleo/+bug/1816026
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/637522/

containers-multinode is a more appropriate
job to fully cover mistral in tripleo.

Change-Id: Ie94e03bdcc14918eb4095e9581d4a935a59b0d6b

commit_message:
Install packages into octavia-api image to support wsgi

This patch adds packages to the octavia-api container to support running
it under apache instead of under simple server. This resolves an issue
with haproxy as well as support IPv6.

Change-Id: I72e0a44f081747ebaec25fd5049db83ea6f418ff
Related-Bug: #1815811

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-02-06 13:54:23.000000000', 'message': 'Set amqp_auto_delete=true for notifications transport.

ironic-neutron-agent uses oslo.messaing notifications
to manage the hash ring members. Each listener uses a
pool, to ensure all instances of the agent recived
notifications from all other isntances of the agent.

The pool used is a random uuid that is generated on
startup, and on restart a new uuid is generated.

In the messaging backend each pool creates a separate
queue. When the agent is restarted this queue is not
removed, and since the uuid is regenerated for the
restarted agent the messaging backend keep publishing
messages to the "old-uuid" queue as well as the
"new-uuid" queue. The problem is that the "old-uuid"
queue is no longer consumed, so it continues to grow

commit_message:
Set amqp_auto_delete=true for notifications transport.

ironic-neutron-agent uses oslo.messaing notifications
to manage the hash ring members. Each listener uses a
pool, to ensure all instances of the agent recived
notifications from all other isntances of the agent.

The pool used is a random uuid that is generated on
startup, and on restart a new uuid is generated.

In the messaging backend each pool creates a separate
queue. When the agent is restarted this queue is not
removed, and since the uuid is regenerated for the
restarted agent the messaging backend keep publishing
messages to the "old-uuid" queue as well as the
"new-uuid" queue. The problem is that the "old-uuid"
queue is no longer consumed, so it continues to grow
and cause high RAM usage in the message broker
back-end.

To fix this set the queues to auto_delete so that
they are deleted automatically when no consumers are
active.

Story: 2004933
Task:  29370
Change-Id: Ie51d0a0b02ed5ea336f3280d84d77cf8fec90ccb
(cherry picked from commit 00c2f2346ad1bcf7179ce1bc304b764f4ebc4cdf)

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-02-19 21:01:23.000000000', 'message': 'Resolve test_datasource_db_sync_add_remove instability

Configure the replica server in the test to use a short PRC timeout.
The instability appears to arise as follows.
In starting the replica Congress instance:
If Congress API process starts before Congress policy engine process,
the call to check Congress started is processed by the API process,
which makes an RPC call to the policy engine process.
But the policy engine process may be a bit slower to start.
In that case, the RPC call may never reach the policy engine process
even if the policy engine process starts up just a few seconds later.
So the call times out according to the default 60 seconds, by which
point the entire retry period of the test is used up and the test
fails.

In this fix, the RPC timeout is set to a short 5 seconds on the
replica instance. That way, if the policy engine has not started
by the time of the first RPC call, the RPC call would time out with
time remaining on the test retry period for further retry.

Change-Id: Ied8c95c4a60a3b6ea2c617fdfe94d4d7cf7a5822
'}, {'created': '2019-02-19 21:10:06.000000000', 'message': 'Resolve test_datasource_db_sync_add_remove instability

by the time of the first RPC call, the RPC call would time out with
time remaining on the test retry period for further retry.

Change-Id: Ied8c95c4a60a3b6ea2c617fdfe94d4d7cf7a5822
'}, {'created': '2019-02-19 23:05:41.000000000', 'message': 'Resolve test_datasource_db_sync_add_remove instability

Configure the replica server in the test to use a short PRC timeout.
The instability appears to arise as follows.
In starting the replica Congress instance:
If Congress API process starts before Congress policy engine process,
the call to check Congress started is processed by the API process,
which makes an RPC call to the policy engine process.
But the policy engine process may be a bit slower to start.
In that case, the RPC call may never reach the policy engine process
even if the policy engine process starts up just a few seconds later.
So the call times out according to the default 60 seconds, by which
point the entire retry period of the test is used up and the test
fails.

In this fix, the RPC timeout is set to a short 10 seconds on the
replica instance. That way, if the policy engine has not started
by the time of the first RPC call, the RPC call would time out with
time remaining on the test retry period for further retry.

The test retry period is also increased because occassionally the
replica policy engine takes longer than the allotted 60s to start up.

Change-Id: Ied8c95c4a60a3b6ea2c617fdfe94d4d7cf7a5822
'}]
commit_message:
Resolve test_datasource_db_sync_add_remove instability

Configure the replica server in the test to use a short PRC timeout.
The instability appears to arise as follows.
In starting the replica Congress instance:
If Congress API process starts before Congress policy engine process,
the call to check Congress started is processed by the API process,
which makes an RPC call to the policy engine process.
But the policy engine process may be a bit slower to start.
In that case, the RPC call may never reach the policy engine process
even if the policy engine process starts up just a few seconds later.
So the call times out according to the default 60 seconds, by which
point the entire retry period of the test is used up and the test
fails.

In this fix, the RPC timeout is set to a short 10 seconds on the
replica instance. That way, if the policy engine has not started
by the time of the first RPC call, the RPC call would time out with
time remaining on the test retry period for further retry.

The test retry period is also increased because occassionally the
replica policy engine takes longer than the allotted 60s to start up.

Change-Id: Ied8c95c4a60a3b6ea2c617fdfe94d4d7cf7a5822

commit_message:
Remove whitespace before comments

Python 2.7 ConfigParser does not accept whitespace before comments.
To keep config files produced by ansible-config_temple parsable
we will strip out the whitespace preceding comments.

Change-Id: I39c88578d0a9e42fded7410d7eb4ec8bd415550c
Related-Bug: #1755821

commit_message:
Add support for nfs cinder volumes

Cinder volumes which are provisioned via nfs need to be mounted on
the compute nodes. For this to work the nfs-common package is needed.

Closes-Bug: #1816820
Change-Id: I5d536817b2098698cecd4627408a82321bf7fb9b

[{'created': '2019-02-14 23:38:49.000000000', 'message': 'Set the default retries down to 120

This patch changes the [haproxy_amphora] connection_max_retries and
build_active_retries default values from 300 to 120. This means load
balancer builds will wait for ten minutes instead of twenty-five minutes
for nova to boot the virtual machine.

We feel these are more reasonable default values for most production
deployments and provide a better user experience.

Only environments running in nested virtualization, without nested
virtualization enabled in the hypervisor could require a value as high as
300.

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/637074
Change-Id: I46be11062fb15ed21169fbec5dc8451a588273a5
'}]
commit_message:
Set the default retries down to 120

This patch changes the [haproxy_amphora] connection_max_retries and
build_active_retries default values from 300 to 120. This means load
balancer builds will wait for ten minutes instead of twenty-five minutes
for nova to boot the virtual machine.

We feel these are more reasonable default values for most production
deployments and provide a better user experience.

Only environments running in nested virtualization, without nested
virtualization enabled in the hypervisor could require a value as high as
300.

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/637074
Change-Id: I46be11062fb15ed21169fbec5dc8451a588273a5

commit_message:
disable murano scenario test in queens-py35 job

Persistent instability in the test on queens branch and only in the
py35 job (py27 seems fine).
The instability makes the test more trouble than it's worth.
Because we are unlikely to make changes to queens going forward,
and even less likely that the changes would break murano integration,
it makes sense to simply disable to test for queens-py35 job, but
keeping it in all other jobs including queens-py27.

Also folding in the following patch resolving gate instability because
both patches are blocked on its own.
---------------------------------------
Increase policy rule create retry limit

Because in the vitrage pub-sub tests, occassionally the retry runs
out before the schema from the datasource is available to the
policy engine to allow the creation of the test rule.

https://review.openstack.org/#/c/637681/

Change-Id: I4915023258b455005e1ac2e2d1492beb368f0184

The firewall won't attempt on update to initialize port in case
port hasn't been initialized by sg_agent yet. This fixes a race where update
rpc call arrives between wiring tap device with integration bridge and
firewall initialization.

Closes-bug: #1740885
"}]
commit_message:
ovsfw: Don't create rules if updated port doesn't exist

The firewall won't attempt on update to initialize port in case
port hasn't been initialized by sg_agent yet. This fixes a race where update
rpc call arrives between wiring tap device with integration bridge and
firewall initialization.

Change-Id: Ice0667df606ae23061acebceea23ab6e49dadbcf
Closes-bug: #1740885

commit_message:
service: updates nova-api-os-compute service to use apache wsgi

Due to an issue in python3 oslo_cache+eventlet when using
memcached. As workaroud for Rocky it has been decided to run service
nova-api-os-compute from systemd to apache2.

Conflicts:
  hooks/nova_cc_hooks.py
    in upgrade_charm() the conflict were because i did not
    cherrypicked the template update for placement api
    (131497868f442bcf06bc199a36e2962b8ac0018d) which does not make
    sens for the purpose of a backport to stable. I removed the
    comment.

  hooks/nova_cc_utils.py
    in disable_package_apache_site() the conflict where also related
    to (131497868f442bcf06bc199a36e2962b8ac0018d).

Closes-Bug: #1812672
Change-Id: I3bf279638c5decf1020345f3d2e876e379144997
Signed-off-by: Sahid Orentino Ferdjaoui <sahid.ferdjaoui@canonical.com>
(cherry picked from commit 13eca55803c8320a401ccf923c29b7bfeb85d0fc)

commit_message:
context: extend HAProxyContext for placement API

Since we will have to generate a HAProxyContext for
nova-compute-os-api, this change add new class
PlacementAPIHAProxyContext which extends HAProxyContext.

Partial-Bug: #1812672
Change-Id: I56920e3d9c5216cdd5a8ea8b83714e65b777a78b
Signed-off-by: Sahid Orentino Ferdjaoui <sahid.ferdjaoui@canonical.com>
(cherry picked from commit fc68571c51d81fd3e9786faebce3946564920ab5)

Update json module to jsonutils

json is deprecated, should use oslo_serialization.jsonutils
instead.

Change-Id: Ib4b562c3f37a5c133f3a6ae8efa00a26c8b41846

[{'created': '2019-02-20 17:24:34.000000000', 'message': 'Add support for nfs cinder volumes

Cinder volumes which are provisioned via nfs are initially mounted
on the cinder node. For this to work the nfs-common package is
needed.

Change-Id: Iac11c262c6e5408303b3afda8633b0252055cfec
Closes-Bug: #1816820
'}]
commit_message:
Add support for nfs cinder volumes

Cinder volumes which are provisioned via nfs are initially mounted
on the cinder node. For this to work the nfs-common package is
needed.

Change-Id: Iac11c262c6e5408303b3afda8633b0252055cfec
Closes-Bug: #1816820

commit_message:
Remove mapping policies from policy.v3cloudsample.json

By incorporating system-scope and default roles, we've effectively
made these policies obsolete. We can simplify what we maintain and
provide a more consistent, unified view of default mapping
behavior by removing them.

Change-Id: Ie01b5a79aaf363b3783c92578f56654b993b5e76
Closes-Bug: 1804519

commit_message:
Add tests for project users interacting with mappings

This commit introduces some tests that show how project users
are expected to behave with the federated mappings API.
A subsequent patch will clean up the now obsolete policies in the
policy.v3cloudsample.json file.

Change-Id: I4c8d8dd8474a8374d68458e3903c379ee44bc731
Related-Bug: 1804519

subject: Add iputils to utility container
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 6816, 'name': 'Jesse Pretorius', 'email': 'jesse@odyssey4.me', 'username': 'jesse-pretorius'}, {'_account_id': 7414, 'name': 'David Wilde', 'email': 'dwilde@redhat.com', 'username': 'd34dh0r53'}, {'_account_id': 21314, 'name': 'Cam J. Loader', 'display_name': 'Cam J. Loader', 'email': 'cameron@loaderusa.net', 'username': '4-cameron'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 25023, 'name': 'Jonathan Rosser', 'email': 'jonathan.rosser@rd.bbc.co.uk', 'username': 'jrosser'}, {'_account_id': 28619, 'name': 'Dmitriy Rabotyagov', 'email': 'noonedeadpunk@gmail.com', 'username': 'noonedeadpunk'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 21314, 'date': '2019-02-19 18:46:49.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 7414, 'date': '2019-02-19 18:49:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 28619, 'date': '2019-02-19 18:53:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Are you sure, that iputils is part of every supported distribution? At least for Ubuntu package should named iputils-ping'}, {'account_id': 28619, 'date': '2019-02-19 18:54:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1'}, {'account_id': 6816, 'date': '2019-02-19 18:54:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

Given that the requirements for pin to be present is in the os_tempest role [1], then that role should install the required package.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/openstack-ansible-os_tempest/commit/f30f002d4b5db1cb30a0b7d669ba19e774e99e8e'}, {'account_id': 7414, 'date': '2019-02-19 20:35:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

Dmitriy is correct in that the package is called iputils-ping, please change that.  I would argue that ping is an essential tool for the utility container.  Since the utility container is a primary location for troubleshooting of the deployment my view is that ping should be considered mandatory.'}, {'account_id': 21314, 'date': '2019-02-19 21:54:01.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 25023, 'date': '2019-02-19 22:11:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

I think this is iputils on centos and iputils-ping on ubuntu so a single package name is not sufficient, OSA group_vars is really not the right place for this sort of thing.

This package addition belongs in the tempest role as that is ultimate source of the dependancy, and that requirement must be carried with the os_tempest role because it is also now consumed by tripleo.

In addition to re-iterate what was said in IRC today pretty much every package not required for the deploy to complete is in the process of being stripped out, having already cut >100Mb off the size of each MNAIO VM this cycle there is still more package removal to come.'}, {'account_id': 21314, 'date': '2019-02-20 19:41:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Abandoning in favor of https://review.openstack.org/#/c/638189/'}, {'account_id': 21314, 'date': '2019-02-20 19:41:41.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned'}, {'account_id': 6816, 'date': '2019-02-21 08:54:43.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

@Dave If there is a desire to add miscellaneous packages which are not gate-essential but are useful for ops, then I'd suggest adding an opt-in list to the utility-install playbook which can be used for that purpose."}]

commit_message:
Add iputils to utility container

The os_tempest role now fails because it cannot find 'ping'. Tempest
pings the router once created.

Change-Id: I26c1014081faf951c46e89aed54c7807d856d536

As a follow up we can figure out a more modern way of handling this.'}, {'account_id': 10273, 'date': '2019-02-14 00:25:15.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 10: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

Agree to disagree?
I guess there's enough cores you don't need my vote. :P"}, {'account_id': 22623, 'date': '2019-02-14 00:28:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 10:

 >

 > I guess there's enough cores you don't need my vote. :P

What are you gaining from this? I personally prefer to keep it consistent with how everyone else does it. :p"}, {'account_id': 11628, 'date': '2019-02-14 00:33:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 10273, 'date': '2019-02-14 01:16:41.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 11.'}, {'account_id': 6469, 'date': '2019-02-14 07:31:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11: Code-Review+2

Great finding, analysis and fix. Thank you, all!'}, {'account_id': 28377, 'date': '2019-02-14 16:00:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 28411, 'date': '2019-02-14 16:50:39.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 11: Code-Review-1

@Erik's approach is correct, not only for consistency sake but also the fact that @Adam's approach introduces a race condition that *still* causes a connection leak.
If multiple thread contexts try call get_client you can have multiple contexts get through the 'if not TRANSPORT:' and create_transport(get_transport_url())
creating more connection leaks, albeit reduced since the window is smaller. This should be reverted to Erik's change, especially since the assert enforces proper initialization"}, {'account_id': 10273, 'date': '2019-02-14 21:18:47.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 11:

@Jim: A few questions here.

1) There is still a single init() for this in prepare_service, which *should* mean those checks are hit exactly as often as the asserts would have been (theoretically never), it's just safer because in the weird unknown case where it might manage to hit one, the thread will be able to save itself instead of terminating.

2) Since this is threaded (not multiproc), doesn't Python's GIL prevent that race from happening? I suppose it's not actually fully atomic, so maybe not..."}, {'account_id': 10273, 'date': '2019-02-14 21:43:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 11:

Even if #2 doesn't apply, I think I'd rather have the rare exception case leak another connection or two than crash the thread with an assertion. This should really be a rare case -- if it weren't rare, the assertion would also be unacceptable."}, {'account_id': 28411, 'date': '2019-02-15 17:27:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:

@Adam Re:1) It "*should* mean those checks are hit exactly as often as the asserts would have been (theoretically never)"
- I agree with the assessment, exactly as often, with drastically different outcomes 
If uninitialized contexts hit the ~fail~ condition assert in the accessor "get_client" they would all fail, they would race into a brick wall :P

Re:2) Fair point, but I cannot definitively speak to the granularity of the GIL in this application without further non-trivial exploration. 

High level discussion regardless, having any memory leaks in favor of stopping bad code/state which will then just fall over later (as it has done) with ambiguous symptoms seems like a poor decision to me.'}, {'account_id': 22623, 'date': '2019-02-16 22:35:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11: Code-Review-1'}, {'account_id': 22623, 'date': '2019-02-16 22:41:18.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 11:

I have never had to -1 my own patch before. I think this is fine, but the change suggested does not make this patch better. I marked it as -1 as I don't agree with the changes, but I still think this patch is a major step in the right direction (in it's current state), as without this we spawn an infinite amount of connections to the RabbitMQ connection.

In our lab we saw over 7 million established connections, and it kept growing exponentially over time."}, {'account_id': 22623, 'date': '2019-02-16 23:37:44.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 11: Code-Review+1

(1 comment)

I'll rather have this very critical patch merged than keep arguing principals."}, {'account_id': 6469, 'date': '2019-02-17 00:10:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11: -Code-Review

I am temporarily reverting my vote until further consensus is reached. My vote was on a patch set not authored by the original committer upon comments that improvements could be made (singleton) and caused more discord. I do acknowledge, as I also did in my earlier review, that the initial rpc.py implementation was very much in line with other projects.'}, {'account_id': 28411, 'date': '2019-02-17 00:24:37.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 11: Code-Review+1

I wont block the patch because its fairly critical, I've said my piece"}, {'account_id': 6469, 'date': '2019-02-18 08:03:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11: Code-Review+2

Thank you, *everyone*!'}, {'account_id': 10273, 'date': '2019-02-18 23:27:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 10273, 'date': '2019-02-18 23:28:56.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 12.'}, {'account_id': 22623, 'date': '2019-02-18 23:29:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 10273, 'date': '2019-02-18 23:36:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12: Code-Review+1

For the record, I think this is what really tipped the scale for me:

https://docs.openstack.org/bandit/latest/plugins/b101_assert_used.html'}, {'account_id': 22623, 'date': '2019-02-18 23:42:40.000000000', 'content': 'Removed reviewer Erik Olof Gunnar Andersson with the following votes:

* Code-Review+1 by Erik Olof Gunnar Andersson <eandersson@blizzard.com>
'}, {'account_id': 10273, 'date': '2019-02-18 23:47:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12:

Ah, as Erik points out, that could also be fixed by following this pattern: https://github.com/openstack/neutron-lib/blob/master/neutron_lib/rpc.py#L74

So, that would be another option, but I am still personally slightly more in favor of the singleton method. But yes, EITHER is so much freaking better than what it does now, it would be good to get either one in.'}, {'account_id': 22623, 'date': '2019-02-18 23:52:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12:

> Ah, as Erik points out, that could also be fixed by following this
 > pattern: https://github.com/openstack/neutron-lib/blob/master/neutron_lib/rpc.py#L74
 > 
 > So, that would be another option, but I am still personally
 > slightly more in favor of the singleton method. But yes, EITHER is
 > so much freaking better than what it does now, it would be good to
 > get either one in.

Yep - I just want to get this merged in. The current state of the patch is more than fine.'}, {'account_id': 6469, 'date': '2019-02-19 08:27:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 11628, 'date': '2019-02-19 16:30:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1

LGTM'}, {'account_id': 22623, 'date': '2019-02-19 18:26:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 11628, 'date': '2019-02-21 00:39:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12:

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-12-20 12:32:17.000000000', 'message': 'Raise exception during init port_forwarding if no l3

L3 plugin is required for port_forwaring plugin to init.
But neutron now could not initiate service plugins in a
particular order of dependency. This patch just raises
an exception during port forwarding plugin initiating.

Related-Bug: #1809238
Change-Id: I53fdaee0cd96a5315a7abc39799657d613eb3a2e

commit_message:
Add dependency for service plugin

Adds a required list 'required_service_plugins' to each service plugin,
then we can initialize the service plugin with required dependency.
And also adds the 'router' plugin to port forwarding service plugin
required list.

Closes-Bug: #1809238
Change-Id: I53fdaee0cd96a5315a7abc39799657d613eb3a2e

commit_message:
Improve invalid port ranges error message

Improve error message that is shown when
port ranges are specified for protocols that don't
support port ranges.

Change-Id: I70ad9bd01f986efaed6682928cc5579c75bd4f6e
Closes-Bug: #1815478
Signed-off-by: Andreas Karis <akaris@redhat.com>

subject: Don't translate event reason when adding hook event
messages:
[{'account_id': 8833, 'date': '2019-02-16 03:44:28.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2019-02-17 21:58:49.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)

Most event reasons are localised because they result from exceptions that generally have internationalised messages. (e.g. ResourceActionRestricted)

This does make the Hook events more consistent, because we don't localise the message when clearing the hook or if the operation is cancelled while a hook is pending.

Ideally the status_reason belongs to the user and they should see localised information. But it seems like it is inevitable that external tools will need to use events to determine when hooks are set, as TripleO does.

I have a suggestion inline, but of course it would break backwards compat for anything relying on the exact text of the message right now."}, {'account_id': 8833, 'date': '2019-02-18 01:28:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)

> Most event reasons are localised because

Right. But We don't seem do it for non-exception based messages i.e I don't see it for stack events[1][2]. So, it's consistent in a way:)


[1] https://github.com/openstack/heat/blob/master/heat/engine/stack.py#L1361
[2] https://github.com/openstack/heat/blob/master/heat/engine/stack.py#L1649"}, {'account_id': 12404, 'date': '2019-02-18 06:19:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1

I tend to agree with this patch for the following reasons,
* The events are useful for condition filter (which I assume that's what TripleO is using)
* We did have multiple places calling _add_event without any translation at all, so we can actually triger a conversation about either we should  to it once for all, or just strip them all out. Therefore, I'm fine with strip this one for now."}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2019-02-18 06:19:36.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)

> So, it's consistent in a way:)

In a good way? :D"}, {'account_id': 8833, 'date': '2019-02-21 07:06:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Cherry Picked

This patchset was cherry picked to branch stable/rocky as commit b4b6a94e72028a08bd9e4d7a2816a4c31f4ee4f8'}, {'account_id': 8833, 'date': '2019-02-21 07:07:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Cherry Picked

This patchset was cherry picked to branch stable/queens as commit 683e6318e2c9738a2621841bc3cf3e3f534eb684'}]

[{'created': '2019-02-16 03:44:28.000000000', 'message': "Don't translate event reason when adding hook event

We don't seem to do it anywhere else. TripleO uses hook
reason string comparsion which does not work if
internationalized.

Story: #2005035
Task: 29524
Change-Id: I3e8f4587966969084cbf1e38406cd3cff23eb9a6
"}]
commit_message:
Don't translate event reason when adding hook event

We don't seem to do it anywhere else. TripleO uses hook
reason string comparsion which does not work if
internationalized.

Story: #2005035
Task: 29524
Change-Id: I3e8f4587966969084cbf1e38406cd3cff23eb9a6

The TC wrote a cloud vision [1] and then asked [2] projects to
do a self-evaluation related to that vision. And, since we have
just released a vision document of Searchlight [3] at Stein-2,
it is a good practice to produce an vision reflection document
to align our work with the rest of OpenStack.

commit_message:
Add a vision-reflection document for Searchlight

The TC wrote a cloud vision [1] and then asked [2] projects to
do a self-evaluation related to that vision. And, since we have
just released a vision document of Searchlight [3] at Stein-2,
it is a good practice to produce an vision reflection document
to align our work with the rest of OpenStack. This patchset is
produced based on the discussion at [4].

[1] https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/technical-vision.html
[2] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-January/001417.html
[3] https://docs.openstack.org/searchlight/latest/contributor/searchlight-vision.html
[4] https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/searchlight-tc-vision-self-eval

Change-Id: I093268758bd5c66ef1ba9d543e9d8ee8156c30f2
Signed-off-by: Trinh Nguyen <dangtrinhnt@gmail.com>

commit_message:
Append qemu-img to Mistral executor package list

The Octavia playbook in tripleo-common and run in Mistral executor fails
because qemu-img is not available. This happens when either the operator
explicitly instructs TripleO to convert the amphora qcow2 file to raw
format or when Ceph is enabled.

This patch appends qemu-img to the package list so that the command is
available in the mistral-executor container.

Closes-Bug: #1816382

Change-Id: I5aba5ba0a800aabe6e662a333e3f0436c1b563a0

commit_message:
Add service checks before trying to configure it

Validate the service/agent is enable before trying to set its
configuration file. Certain deployment does not use OVS or l3 agents
like Contrail.

Change-Id: I8ad30f1754ca7560c341ff67fe2a446f1280e124
Closes-Bug: #1815609

commit_message:
Adding support of glance cinder store settings

Currently TripleO is completely unaware of the 4 glance
settings when cinder backend of glance is enabled.

To make the Image-Volume in the internal project accessible from
the Image service, the below parameters need to be set.

- cinder_store_auth_address
- cinder_store_project_name
- cinder_store_user_name
- cinder_store_password

Conflicts:
      puppet/services/glance-api.yaml

Closes-Bug: #1809104
Change-Id: I15f9c286798b74529a7b4b09d7e9353eb715f5b1
(cherry picked from commit d9a43277e5266e9d25061a4c16f0384529b46da4)
